CVRep breathes new life into musical 'Ballroom'

Autor: BLUESKYE, BRIAN. 

Información de publicación: The Desert Sun ; Palm Springs, Calif. [Palm Springs, Calif]. 09 Feb 2020: C.3.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/cvrep-breathes-new-life-into-musical-ballroom/docview/2352384108/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=CVRep+breathes+new+life+into+musical+%27Ballroom%27&amp;author=BLUESKYE%2C+BRIAN&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=C.3&amp;date=2020-02-09&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Desert+Sun&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Awestnews_

Texto completo: A musical premiered on Broadway in 1978 called "Ballroom," starring Dorothy Loudon and Vincent Gardenia. It was directed and choreographed by Michael Bennett, who had just come off a wave of success after "A Chorus Line."
Set in New York, "Ballroom" follows a widow named Bea who is convinced by her friend Angie to start experiencing the highs of life again at the Stardust Ballroom, where many escape on the weekend and let loose dancing to cha-cha, merengue and waltz. Bea agrees and ends up meeting a man named Al, who she falls for.
Even though Bennett won a Tony Award for the choreography, the show didn't draw audiences and closed after a few months. The only memory of "Ballroom" is the song "Fifty Percent," which is popular in cabaret.
But CVRep in Cathedral City is out to change that. The 11-year-old theater company bought the rights to the original musical, rewrote the script and worked with the original composer Billy Goldenberg and original lyricist Alan Bergman on the music.
According to CVRep's founding Artistic Director Ron Celona, this is the biggest production the theater has taken on, costing the small company $225,000 that has to be recouped through ticket sales. The show comprises a cast of 26 people, nine musicians and several stagehands.
"I promised my board this won't become a habit, and this is an opportunity," Celona told The Desert Sun. "I have to commend my board for that. They really supported the dream of this project and understood that, but the size of this production is risky."
It all started with 'Fifty Percent' Celona had interest in reviving "Ballroom" after seeing Lucie Arnaz perform "Fifty Percent" at local photographer Michael Childers' "One Night Only" fundraiser for the Barbara Sinatra Center for Abused Children at the McCallum Theatre last May. A fan of the 1975 TV movie "Queen of the Stardust Ballroom" starring Maureen Stapleton and Charles Durning, which the musical adaptation is based on, Celona wondered, "Whatever happened to 'Ballroom?'"
"I saw that movie when I was a little kid and the movie also had music in it. I remember it being a sentimental, wonderful, warm, fuzzy experience that was a big sensation," Celona said.
Through a mutual friend in Indian Wells, Celona made contact with Goldenberg, the original composer, last June. Celona met with the 84-year old in a coffee shop in New York City to find out what went wrong with the original Broadway production, and to see if there was any way for CVRep to revive it.
"(Director) Michael Bennett basically came off 'A Chorus Line' as a huge success and bought the rights to the show. He made it a dance show," Celona said. "The story line got minimized. There were these big, flashy, beautiful dance production numbers done by two band singers that had no relationship to the people in the story. I think that was a major flaw in the original. There wasn't enough substance and the audience didn't have a relationship with the characters."
Goldenberg told The Desert Sun it was a "huge disappointment" to him, as well as to the original lyricists.
"It was nowhere near the version we expected," Goldenberg said. "Through the years, the only script that has been sent to theaters is the original script, so we never had a chance to see it in its full-blown form, and (writer Jerome Kass) brewed on this script since we did it on Broadway and unfortunately passed away."
Film producer John Breglio, who wrote the book "I Wanna Be a Producer: How to Make a Killing on Broadway...or Get Killed," said during a 2016 interview that collaboration among creatives behind the show "failed."
"The collaboration among the writer, the composer, the lyricist and Michael (Bennett) never gelled," said Breglio, who was put in charge of Bennett's estate after his death in 1987, according to the New York Times. "Marilyn Bergman, who was a great Academy Award lyricist started being a mother figure to Michael and ended up despising him. Michael didn't respect anybody working on the show because they didn't do what he to do. Jerome Kass was running the book and it was his story, and he was upset because Michael wanted more humor in the piece and Jerome didn't want any humor, so Michael brought in (director) Mike Nichols to write some stuff. It just got worse and worse."
But before CVRep could move ahead with a new version, they had to attain the rights, which were owned by Samuel French, Inc., a publisher of plays. Goldenberg didn't think it would be possible, but Celona knew Samuel French had been purchased by Concord Music, owned by composer and theater director Andrew Lloyd Weber, in 2018.
CVRep's attorney attained the rights last June from Kass' widow, the Michael Bennett estate and Concord Music, Celona said. It required a large deposit as insurance until final box office figures are reported, but Celona would not disclose the cost of the deposit.
Concord Music did not respond to The Desert Sun's requests for comment.
"They looked at the history of how many people are producing Ballroom, next to zero. No one wants to do it because it's a problem script," Celona said. "If I can make it a better script and musical the way they see it as, it then becomes a marketable product to sell to regional theaters all over the world and it makes money,"
'I wanted to make this feel like real life' Once they attained the rights to the musical, CVRep musical director Scott Storr, Bergman and Goldenberg started collaborating on new songs for the production.
But casting "Ballroom" was difficult because it requires older actors and actresses who can sing and dance, as well as look and act like working-class people. Celona searched for people in Los Angeles and New York.
"I didn't want them to have the body or looks of a stereotype and I didn't want a beautiful chorus. That's not what this is show should be in my head and I wanted to make this feel like real life," Celona said.
Actress, singer and dancer Melodie Wolford, who has also been in a production of "La Cage aux Folles" and had roles on the TV shows "Law and Order: Special Victims Unit," "The Perfect Murder" and "New Amsterdam," was cast as Bea.
Broadway veteran Bill Nolte, who has performed in productions of "Cats," the early '90s revival of "Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat," "La Cage aux Folles," "1776" and "The Producers," was cast as Al, Bea's love interest.
Like Celona, Nolte is familiar with the story and saw it on Broadway in 1979. He jumped at the chance to play the male lead because of the music and the song "Fifty Percent."
"'Fifty Percent' became an anthem for women in New York because it's so well written," Nolte said. "I always wondered why 'Ballroom' didn't fly, and this is a chance to tweak it and see if we can find what will make it fly. I think we're off to a good start. The fact that we're working with the actual living composer and lyricist is exciting."
Playing Al also comes with the challenge of the character's secret. Nolte described the role as "problematic," and one that starts off as awkward.
"He doesn't really dance with anyone because he can't find a partner," Nolte said. "He's a mailman from the Bronx who is rather ordinary, and when he meets Bea and she finally agrees to dance with them, they discover they're both kind of awkward in this Stardust Ballroom and together they make a good team."
Wolford said "Ballroom" is her dream role. She listened to the Broadway recording with friends while attending University of Southern Mississippi 40 years ago and proclaimed she would one day play the role of Bea on Broadway.
But, as a singer, it has come with a challenge.
"(Original cast member) Dorothy Loudon, who was spectacular, had five songs. I have 10 songs. I'm a soprano and this is not a soprano role. It's been a challenge, but I'm working very hard," Wolford said.
The cast also includes Teri Ralston, one of the original stars of the Broadway musical "Company," playing the role of Angie, a waitress and friend to Bea.
If you go
What: "Ballroom"
When: Through Feb. 16
Where: CVRep, 68-510 E. Palm Canyon Dr., Cathedral City
How much: $53-$73
Information: (760) 296-2966

Facial recognition gets scrutiny in NJ

Autor: BARCHENGER, STACEY. 

Información de publicación: Daily Record ; Morristown, N.J. [Morristown, N.J]. 09 Feb 2020: A.8.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/facial-recognition-gets-scrutiny-nj/docview/2352383928/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Facial+recognition+gets+scrutiny+in+NJ&amp;author=BARCHENGER%2C+STACEY&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.8&amp;date=2020-02-09&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Daily+Record&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: Private companies create huge databases of images from social media. Ring doorbell cameras give police intimate access to citizens' front porches. And now New Jersey leaders are weighing what to do about the use of your pictures in face-matching programs.
Amid local and national concerns over privacy rights, the state's top cop, the attorney general, is working on a policy that would dictate when prosecutors and police across the state can use facial recognition technology.
At least one state lawmaker says it's time to put a pause on use of the technology, a moratorium that would allow lawmakers to work out rules or decide whether it should be banned entirely.
And this is happening as an unanswered question looms: How widely is the technology used in New Jersey?
"We don't know who is using it, we don't know how they're using it," said Assemblyman Andrew Zwicker, D-Mercer. In fact there's a bevy of questions surrounding the relatively new technology, he said.
"Who is using it?" he said. "Is it accurate? What are they doing with that information? Who are they sharing that information with? What's the impact on someone's life who has now been identified?"
Zwicker introduced a bill that would require law enforcement agencies to hold public hearings before using facial recognition technology. But after a nearly two-hour hearing earlier this week when experts raised concern about accuracy of the technology and individual privacy, Zwicker said he's exploring what more may need to be done.
"Making sure we're in front of this now is critically important," he said, noting the rapid pace at which technology advances.
Facial recognition software compares two images for similarities. It can be used to verify someone's identity as a security measure by comparing just two images, or to identify one picture among a group of images, such as comparing a suspect photograph with a group of mugshots. It can unlock your iPhone or iPad and will be used this year to identify athletes competing in the Tokyo Olympics, the first time facial recognition has been used in Olympic history.
While the technology has been around for decades, advancements have made it more affordable and more accessible for private sector use, said Jake Parker, a lobbyist for the industry group Security Industry Association, whose members include facial recognition developers and security companies.
Images used for comparison can come from in-house databases, like a police department's mugshot collection, or more controversially, private companies like Clearview AI, an app that says it pulled billions of photos from across the web, including social sites like Facebook.
One in two American adults were in a law enforcement picture database in 2016, according to a nationwide analysis by Georgetown Law's Center on Privacy & Technology. The analysis urged governments to regulate use of the technology, which it said was less accurate than fingerprint analysis, to protect individuals' rights and civil liberties.
Yet it is the collection of images by Clearview AI that has sparked a fire recently in New Jersey. Earlier this month, after The New York Times revealed the extensive cache of images collected by Clearview AI, and that it was working with more than 600 police departments across the country, New Jersey Attorney General Gurbir Grewal told law enforcement officers across the state to stop using it.
Grewal's office is working on issuing a statewide directive to law enforcement about when and how they can use facial recognition technology, Assistant Attorney General B. Stephan Finkel told lawmakers this week. Also underway is a survey to understand which departments were using Clearview AI, Deputy Director of the Division of Criminal Justice Christine Hoffman told lawmakers. Clifton and Livingston police used the program, according to testimony at the hearing.
"We still have only preliminary results but the majority of the counties that have reported in were exploring it on a trial basis and in many cases simply ran officers' photos through the system," Hoffman said. "So I would not characterize this as extensive use at this point in time based upon those results."
But that's just for Clearview AI, not the hundreds of other private companies now offering facial recognition services.
It's not clear how extensively the technology is being used in New Jersey. A spokesman for the attorney general declined to answer questions about which police departments use it.
In Newark, the state's largest city, officials confirmed police use facial recognition to help identify possible suspects. "It has worked well for us over the past few years, especially in cases of robberies and burglaries where surveillance cameras are typically available to capture good quality, up-close suspect images," Newark Department of Public Safety Director Anthony F. Ambrose said in a statement.
Newark police keep their own database of images for comparison and can also access one maintained by New Jersey State Police, he said. A spokeswoman said police do not use facial recognition on the citywide system of publicly accessible surveillance cameras known as Citizens Virtual Patrol.
The state Department of Motor Vehicles has used the technology for years, scouring their in-house database of more than 23 million driver photographs to detect duplicates that could signal fraud. More than 100 people were brought up on criminal charges as a result, the state announced in 2014.
The technology is not used by law enforcement in many of the state's largest cities, including Camden, Edison, Jersey City, Lakewood and Toms River, according to police officials or spokespeople in each of those jurisdictions. At least 30 police departments in New Jersey have agreements with Amazon-owned Ring doorbell cameras to access videos, though it's unclear if they're also using facial recognition technology.
The American Civil Liberties Union of New Jersey says facial recognition shouldn't be used anywhere, pointing to severe consequences including wrongful arrest that could come based on an incorrect identification.
Six cities in California and Massachusetts have banned the use of facial recognition technology, according to Molly Linhorst, a law fellow at the ACLU of New Jersey. Three states — California, Oregon and New Hampshire — have banned its use only for body-worn cameras, but none have banned it completely, she said.
A federal government study in December evaluated the accuracy of nearly 200 algorithms used in facial recognition software and found vast disparities in results, including that a single algorithm could have different accuracy rates for different demographic groups. For example, some algorithms had higher false positive rates when identifying images of African American women among a group of comparison images, according to the report from the National Institute of Standards and Technology.
"There is a lot about today's technology and its limits that we do not understand," Linhorst told lawmakers this week. "The fact that this technology proves so unreliable, and is more likely to harm communities that already experience significant discrimination and bias provides reason for us to stop acquiring and using facial recognition technology."
Zwicker suggested the technology could lead to widespread government surveillance, citing the classic dystopian novel by George Orwell.
"The biggest area of concern I have, an Orwellian '1984' scenario is the government having a surveillance state," he said. "We're in a place where our entire lives just about are happening online."
Email: sbarchenger@gannettnj.com Phone: 732-427-0114 Twitter: @sbarchenger

Culinary star has a taste for hard work

Autor: Hutcheson, Susannah. 

Información de publicación: The Greenville News ; Greenville, S.C. [Greenville, S.C]. 09 Feb 2020: E.5.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/culinary-star-has-taste-hard-work/docview/2352383363/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Culinary+star+has+a+taste+for+hard+work%3A+Roman+likes+the+variety+her+jobs+can+serve+up&amp;author=Hutcheson%2C+Susannah&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=E.5&amp;date=2020-02-09&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Greenville+News&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asoutheastnews_

Texto completo: Our series "How I became a ..." digs into the stories of accomplished and influential people, finding out how they got to where they are in their careers.
From her beginnings working in the restaurant scene to becoming a cook with viral recipes such as #TheCookies and #TheStew, Alison Roman is quite the culinary jill-of-all-trades. As the bestselling author of cookbooks "Dining In" and "Nothing Fancy" as well as a columnist for New York Times Cooking and Bon Appétit, Roman always has her hands on a keyboard or working on a stovetop.
USA TODAY caught up with the food writer and chef extraordinaire to talk about everything from Joan Didion and oat milk to learning to say no and consistently cultivating staying power in everything she does.
Question: How did you get your start?
Alison Roman: I started by working in kitchens, working in restaurants as a pastry cook. That looks very different than my life does now, but I was working in restaurants and doing service and coming up with dishes that went on menus, things like that.
It basically all relates to each other. I don't think that I would have been as strong of a writer about food had I not cooked professionally and had that background experience. It also teaches you a ridiculous work ethic that is challenging to find elsewhere.
Q: What does a typical day look like for you?
Roman: A typical day is super atypical. It really depends – if I'm shooting photos or videos or shopping for those things, or I'm doing neither and I'm writing or traveling or running errands and trying to stay on top of my general life administration. I feel like I do so many different things all the time that there truly is no typical day, which makes things very challenging.
Q: What's your favorite part about your job?
Roman: It's different all the time; it pushes me creatively and intellectually, and I get to have contact with people and teach them things and have an impact on their lives. It's a completely unique experience to be in people's homes and be a part of their lives, even if it feels one-sided because I don't actually know them. But, just to have a lasting impact that feels a bit different than, say, cooking for them in a restaurant (which can obviously have a really deep impact, but it's just a different style).
Q: To what do you credit your success?
Roman: Really hard work, and not letting things that I find challenging deter me. I think that I have come up against a lot of things that I struggled with, but I've never thought that meant I shouldn't be doing what I wanted to be doing.
Q: How do you balance work, life, and such a busy schedule?
Roman: That's something I'm working on. I think that as I get more secure in my career and more successful, it's much easier for me to kind of say no to things and to make time for myself, my friends, and protect my space and personal life. I find that to be easier and easier, and I think I'm getting there. But, just understanding that I'm not going to be very good at my job or to anyone else if I am feeling run ragged because I haven't set aside any time for myself.
Q: What have been some career highlights?
Roman: I'll never forget the first time I was published in Bon Appetit, I'll never forget the first time I got a job as a pastry chef, I'll never forget being recognized for the things that I was putting on menus in restaurants, I'll never forget my first column in The New York Times or making The New York Times bestseller's list, or these milestones that I feel like only happen once that truly do feel so, so special.
Q: What advice would you give to someone who wants to follow in your footsteps?
Roman: Try different things. Always say yes. Push yourself. Just know that it's not going to be easy. Nothing just falls into your lap, and if it does it's not going to last for very long. You have to constantly be thinking about how to make something secure and stable. Things will come your way, and you may achieve a small amount of success by accident, but in order to really keep it and have staying power, you have to actually work at it, and work really hard. It's like a plant that you have to water and feed and take care of.
Quick hits
What's your coffee order? Oat milk cortado, iced black, or a regular black.
What's your favorite book? I'm really bad at favorites, but I'm rereading "Slouching Towards Bethlehem" right now, which is so good.
What's your favorite song at the moment? I've been listening to a lot of King Princess.
Who have been your biggest mentors? I've been really lucky to have many mentors in the various stages of my career, but I have two chefs I worked for – Ron Mendoza and William Werner – who really helped shape a lot of my work ethic and basic understanding of pastry, cooking, and baking. As I moved more into editorial, I had a lot of really great champions. Christine Muhlke and Adam Rapoport were both so wonderful at championing me and pursuing my own thing.
What's the coolest thing you've ever done? My whole life is really cool. I feel very fortunate and happy to have done several cool things. I was actually just thinking that today while we were shooting videos for The New York Times. I find as much joy in that as if I'm recording [a podcast] with NPR or going on a vacation to Mexico. The coolest thing I've done is shape my life to be able to do a bunch of cool things.
CREDIT: Susannah Hutcheson

Opinion: Iowa debacle might impact Florida

Autor: Anderson, Zac. 

Información de publicación: Florida Today ; Melbourne, Fla. [Melbourne, Fla]. 09 Feb 2020: A.2.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/opinion-iowa-debacle-might-impact-florida/docview/2352383113/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Opinion%3A+Iowa+debacle+might+impact+Florida%3A+Sunshine+State%27s+primary+could+be+important+one&amp;author=Anderson%2C+Zac&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.2&amp;date=2020-02-09&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Florida+Today&amp;issn=1051-8304&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asoutheastnews_

Texto completo: The Democratic presidential nominating contest got off to a disastrous start last week when the Iowa caucus experienced a complete meltdown, but the candidates don't have time to dwell on what happened in the caucus calamity.
New Hampshire votes Tuesday, and Democrats in other states – including Florida – already are casting early ballots.
Florida elections supervisors sent vote-by-mail ballots to military and overseas presidential primary voters at the beginning of February, and domestic ballots started going out last week.
More than 1.2 million Floridians voted absentee in the 2016 presidential primary, including 520,035 Democrats and 713,857 Republicans.
In Florida's Democratic president primary, absentee voters made up one-third of the electorate in 2016.
With a big presidential field that is attracting plenty of attention, and a deep feeling among Democrats that they need to find a strong challenger to take on President Donald Trump, many Democrats are eager to cast primary ballots this year. The number of Democrats requesting absentee ballots for the 2020 primary already is way up in some Florida counties.
Brevard County Supervisor of Elections Lori Scott said 1,994 mail ballots were sent out on Jan. 31 to overseas military and overseas civilian voters for the March 17 presidential primary. In addition, her office is scheduled to mail an additional 82,352 domestic mail ballots on Feb. 13.
As of Friday, there were 182,286 registered Republicans and 133,365 registered Democrats in Brevard.
While Florida's presidential primary is underway, it's still not clear what role the state ultimately will play in choosing the nominee.
Florida Democrats will see 16 names on their presidential primary ballot, including candidates who already have dropped out, such as Corey Booker and Julian Castro. More candidates likely will drop out before Florida's March 17 primary date, but the ballot had to be finalized back in December to allow time for printing.
Most of the candidates who are still in the race haven't had much of a presence in Florida so far, but a few have invested early and that could pay off if the state is competitive.
The four early voting states – Iowa, New Hampshire, South Carolina and Nevada – get most of the candidate attention early on because wins there can provide much-needed momentum and fundraising, while losses can cause support to collapse.
But if the race remains muddled deep into the primary calendar, Florida could play a key role in the nomination. That scenario looks more likely now, with Iowa's vote-counting problems resulting in the state failing to give the type of big lift or devastating defeat that can help winnow the field.
Former Vice President Joe Biden had a disappointing performance in Iowa, but it was overshadowed by the caucus dysfunction.
If Biden can rebound in some of the other early voting states, Florida could help propel him further. He consistently has led in the polls here, and likely is locking in absentee votes before other candidates have a chance to focus on targeting Florida voters.
"As vote-by-mail gears up across Florida, we feel energized by the growing support we have across the state," said Jackie Lee, the senior advisor for Biden's Florida campaign, in announcing five more endorsements from Florida elected officials last week, bringing the total to 50 endorsements in the state. "These legislators are well-known, influential leaders that know Joe Biden is the candidate best-positioned to beat Donald Trump in the critical state of Florida."
Former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg also could benefit from the confusion in Iowa. Bloomberg got into the race late and is not competing in the early states. Instead, the billionaire is spending enormous sums in states that vote in March, including Florida.
Bloomberg already has spent millions on television advertising in Florida and has more than 100 campaign staffers working in field offices around the state. He is betting that no candidate will come out of the early nominating contests strong enough to match his resources, and Iowa's diminished influence helps that strategy.
Bloomberg told the New York Times last week he was doubling his ad spending in every market where he currently is on TV – which includes Florida – after the problems in Iowa.
Bloomberg's army of campaign workers, coupled with the heavy advertising, could help him amass absentee votes in Florida before other candidates have a chance to build a ground game.
"We have a lot of staff on the ground that is going to be communicating with voters, we're going to be talking to them at their doors and you're going to see a lot more ads from us through the election," said Scott Kosanovich, who is running Bloomberg's Florida campaign.
The other top tier candidates – Elizabeth Warren, Bernie Sanders, Pete Buttigieg and Amy Klobuchar – all have a limited Florida campaigns right now and are banking on generating momentum in other primaries that will carry over into the state.
That strategy is still the best bet to win the nomination based on historical precedence, but if the race stays competitive the campaigns eventually will need to start ramping up in Florida.
Aside from Bloomberg, Warren and Biden may have the most robust Florida campaigns among the top tier candidates.
Biden has a network of supporters and donors that has been built up over many years. Warren opened a campaign office in Miami in September, opened a second office in the state, in Orlando, earlier this month and has been hiring Florida campaign workers.
"From the very beginning we invested in Florida before any other campaign has; we were the first to put staff on the ground," said Kim Diaz Scott, who is running Warren's Florida campaign with a staff of more than 20.
"Everything that we are doing is because we were well aware that a little under half of Florida's primary voting base will be voting before March 17," Scott added. "That's why we needed to invest early."
Sanders still has plenty of supporters in Florida who have been with him since his 2016 campaign. But he got crushed by Hillary Clinton in Florida's 2016 presidential primary and does not appear to be investing heavily in the state so far this cycle, although he recently hired a Florida field director.
Buttigieg and Klobuchar also don't appear to have much campaign infrastructure in the state, although Klobuchar won satellite caucuses in St. Petersburg and Port Charlotte that the Iowa Democratic Party put on for the first time this cycle.
Whether Florida proves to be a pivotal battleground in the primary remains to be seen.
Candidates who haven't invested in the state may not pay much of a price if they build up enough momentum before Floridians vote.
But the debacle in Iowa made it more likely that Florida's primary matters.
Residents check in after arriving at an Iowa Democratic caucus at Hoover High School on Feb. 3 in Des Moines, Iowa.
Charlie Neibergall/AP
CREDIT: Zac Anderson

Rancho Mirage Writers Festival hosts Angel Night

Autor: GRIBOW, DALE. 

Información de publicación: The Desert Sun ; Palm Springs, Calif. [Palm Springs, Calif]. 09 Feb 2020: E.5.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/rancho-mirage-writers-festival-hosts-angel-night/docview/2352382462/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Rancho+Mirage+Writers+Festival+hosts+Angel+Night&amp;author=GRIBOW%2C+DALE&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=E.5&amp;date=2020-02-09&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Desert+Sun&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Awestnews_

Texto completo: In "A Tale of Two Cities," Charles Dickens opened with "It was the best of times ..." Truly that describes the "Coachellafest for the mind," also known as the 2020 Rancho Mirage Writers Festival.
At the seventh annual "Angel Night" dinner on Tuesday, Jan. 28, which proceeds the three-day festival at the Rancho Mirage Library and Observatory, 600 bibliophiles and members of the fourth estate attended. The 2020 theme was "The Election and the Anniversary of Women's Right to Vote," and guests were eager to soak up their yearly allotment of literary knowledge at the Super Bowl of Writers Festivals, which took place a few days before the Iowa Caucus.
Festival founder Jamie Kabler and his team — which includes Debbie Green Miller, Deborah Dejah and the library's director Aaron Espinosa — plan the festival two years in advance, and their meticulousness showed in every detail. "Organized" best describes the event; attendees were greeted by a phalanx of valet attendants and Mariachis. Offerings were plentiful, with stations for coffee, pastries, water, mixed candies and ample boxed lunches. Writers and speakers were able to meet and greet, thus fulfilling one of the festival's missions.
The mind-stimulating festival was made possible by Founding Angel Helene Galen, joined by Platinum Angels Sherrie Auen, Catharine Reed and Harold Matzner. These generous donors, in addition to other Angels, helped to underwrite the festival so that there was no increase in price.
"The Rancho Mirage Writers Festival is an amazing opportunity to hear from dynamic authors on a variety of topics," Reed said. "This year, we're excited that the Auen Foundation's sponsorship will make every presentation available online." (For information, visit rmwritersfest.org.)
James Patterson, the world's best-selling author and the literary equivalent of a rock star, graced the stage to the delight of the attendees. His presentation began the 2020 literary journey, where more than 1,300 readers were intrigued by presenters who rotated every 45 minutes with often seven diverse presentations daily.
Patterson was interviewed by journalist Carl Hiassen, and each shared their great sense of humor. Patterson opened, describing the desert as "a place where I am not the oldest in the room." Patterson's latest novel about Jeffrey Epstein, "Filthy Rich," was one of several books gifted to attendees.
Some notables in the crowd were Angels Patty Newman, G. Aubrey and Lori Serfling, Jan Salta, Bryn and Dick Debeikes, Bob and Wendy Goodfriend, Anne Holland, Marion Rosenthal, Edye Broad and Dan Clivner and Lori and Mike Milken.
Dr. Barry and Gale Hackshaw, Patty Newman, G. Aubrey and Lori Serfling, Bruce Fessier, Carol Scherger, Dr. Joe Scherger, co-chair Dr. Bart Ketover and attorney Steve Quintinalla, who handles the festival's legal work.
Some of the laudatory festival descriptions heard were from Dave Barry, who commented it was "the best writers festival in the universe." Bret Stephens of The New York Times and The Wall Street Journal said: "The Writers Festival is the best of its kind and will soon be a landmark institution of the literate American culture."
The festival pulsed with inspiring and diverse panels and conversations. Among the selections were "America's First War" with Dr. Lynne Cheney and Jon Meacham; "Is America a Country at War With Itself?" with James Fallows, Senator Jeff Flake, Karl Rove and Bret Stephens; "The Fan and the Commissioner" with Dr. Doris Kearns Goodwin and Bud Selig; "No Safe Spaces" with congresswoman Jackie Speier; "The End of Alzheimers" with Dr. Dale Bredesen, interviewed by Eisenhower 360's Scherger; "Presidential Politics and the Media" with ABC's Dan Abrams and "Happiness Revisited" by Dennis Prager.
If guests expected to be spoiled, they were not disappointed. Among those departing with smiling faces, from what surely will be the talk of the desert until next year's event on January 26-29, 2021, were Connie and Bob Lurie, Donna MacMillan, Mary Hart, Iris and Thom Smotrich, Bruce Konheim, Michael Landes, Sharon Davis and former governor of California Gray Davis.
Dale Gribow is a trial lawyer representing the injured and criminally accused. He has been named Man of the Year seven times (City of Palm Desert and the City of Hope) and had Dale Gribow Day declared four times. He was selected as a "Top Lawyer" by Palm Springs Life and Inland Empire magazines. He serves as president of 12 nonprofits and is a member of 40 boards.
Seventh annual 'Angel Night' dinner kicking off the Rancho Mirage Writers Festival

Staff to be restructured after Black History outrage

Autor: Johnson, Mark. 

Información de publicación: Lansing State Journal ; Lansing, Mich. [Lansing, Mich]. 09 Feb 2020: A.6.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/staff-be-restructured-after-black-history-outrage/docview/2352382206/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Staff+to+be+restructured+after+Black+History+outrage%3A+President+apologizes+for+display+at+Wharton+Center&amp;author=Johnson%2C+Mark&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.6&amp;date=2020-02-09&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Lansing+State+Journal&amp;issn=0274-9742&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Amidwestnews1_

Texto completo: EAST LANSING – Michigan State University President Samuel Stanley said staff at the Wharton Center is being restructured after a gift shop display of dolls depicting black historical figures hanging from a rack resembling a tree led to widespread outrage.
In a letter he sent to the MSU community on Thursday and posted on the president's website, Stanley apologized for the display. He promised the university is taking the situation seriously and taking steps to prevent such incidents from occurring in the future.
"This was a disturbing reminder of our country's history of terror and unrelenting brutality that targeted individuals based on their race," Stanley wrote. "Members of our community were hurt. Though this display was created to honor prominent African Americans during Black History Month, we cannot ignore the historical context that made it exceedingly painful and traumatic to our community members.
"This display was unacceptable and should never have been put up. I'm sorry that this happened. It has been taken down. We can, and must, do better as Spartans. We need to do the necessary work that better informs our thinking and deepens our understanding of how our actions affect others."
"The center is undergoing a full restructuring of staff, including management," Stanley wrote in the letter. More details were not in the letter, but Dan Olsen, an MSU spokesman, said the reorganization will be confined to gift shop staff.
Stanley wrote that diversity within the center's workforce would be a priority.
All staff and volunteers also will go through mandatory racial-bias education and development starting Wednesday in coordination with the MSU Office for Inclusion and Intercultural Initiatives.
Olsen said the Wharton Center will reevaluate the roles and responsibilities for gift shop workers and volunteers. A final determination will be made once those employees and volunteers complete the racial-bias education and development.
Additional plans are in the works to make a diversity, equity, and inclusion committee consisting of faculty, staff, students, volunteers and other community members to "bring a diverse range of identities and perspectives to the Wharton Center," according to Stanley.
"There is no denying this happened on our campus, at a location that was meant to recognize the contributions of MSU's past president, Clifton R. Wharton Jr., a great American and MSU leader and his wife, Dolores Wharton, who both came to campus with a deep appreciation for the arts," Stanley wrote in the letter. "We have work to do."
Wharton, 93, served as MSU's president from 1970 to 1978. His tenure at MSU marked the first time a black president was selected by a major university where the majority of students were white, the New York Times reported. Wharton left MSU to serve as chancellor of the State University of New York and later held business and diplomatic roles, including Under Secretary of State in the Clinton Administration.
While at MSU, Wharton and his wife Dolores promoted the plan to build a new performance venue to replace the aging MSU Auditorium. They also headed the successful fundraising campaign. When the new performing arts center opened in 1982, it was named in their honor.
The display in the gift shop was discovered last week. It featured a rack resembling a tree to hang felt ornaments resembling Michelle Obama, Barack Obama, Prince and other African-American leaders.
Krystal Rose Davis-Dunn, a 31-year-old black graduate student at MSU, came across the displays after a jazz concert she had attended with a friend who wanted to check out the gift shop after the show. The dolls hanging from the tree was one of the first things she noticed when they walked in.
They kept walking around and she spotted four or five similar trees and a larger tree with "a lot more" black leaders.
"The Wharton Center recognizes the need for greater diversity among its staff and volunteers and for creating an environment that reflects our best efforts. However, they are not alone in that need," Stanley wrote. "Our entire campus must view this as an opportunity to learn and reflect on what we can and should do to create a safe and inclusive culture, and we must hold ourselves accountable for achieving these goals."
Contact Mark Johnson at 517-377-1026 or at majohnson2@lsj.com. Follow him on Twitter at @ByMarkJohnson.
Michigan State University removed an ornament display of African-American leaders hanging from a tree at the Wharton Center gift shop, shown on Jan. 30.
Krystal Rose Davis-Dunn

Church closes Tiffany's fundraising lead in primary

Autor: Schulte, Laura. 

Información de publicación: Wausau Daily Herald ; Wausau, Wis. [Wausau, Wis]. 09 Feb 2020: A.5.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/church-closes-tiffanys-fundraising-lead-primary/docview/2352382064/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Church+closes+Tiffany%27s+fundraising+lead+in+primary&amp;author=Schulte%2C+Laura&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.5&amp;date=2020-02-09&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Wausau+Daily+Herald&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Amidwestnews1_

Texto completo: Since October, Republican Jason Church has outraised Tom Tiffany in the GOP primary race for the 7th Congressional District, nearly closing the gap on the state senator's early fundraising lead.
That's according to the numbers released by the Federal Elections Commission on Thursday. The reports also show that in the Democratic primary for the 7th Disrtict, Tricia Zunker has raised over $145,000, while her opponent, Lawrence Dale, hadn't filed a finance report as of Friday afternoon.
USA TODAY NETWORK-Wisconsin examined campaign finances reports for the candidates in the special election for the 7th District. The reports cover the current election cycle, which runs through Jan. 29. The totals include individual donations as well as money received from PACs, loans and offsets to operating expenditures, such as rebates.
The four candidates are vying to replace former Rep. Sean Duffy. The Republican lawmaker stepped down at the end of September, forcing a special election. The primary is Feb. 18 and the election is May 12.
Republican candidates Church, of Hudson, raised all of his money — $658,000 in contributions — since Sept. 24, according to his FEC filings. State Sen. Tiffany, of Minocqua, brought in about $477,000 in donations since Oct. 1, bringing his total to more than $719,000, according to his FEC filings.
Church's donors came from 35 states and Washington, D.C. Among his donors were Michael Heyer, the owner of Racine Danish Kringle, who gave $1,000; William Hsu of Hsu's Ginseng in Wausau, who gave $2,800; and John Kemmerer, an owner of Jackson Hole Mountain resort in Wyoming, who gave $2,800. Church also received over $261,000 in donations from WinRed, an online fundraising platform created by the Republican Party.
Tiffany's donors came from 20 states and Washington, D.C. Among his donors were Duffy, who gave $2,000; Ashley Furniture president Todd Wanek, who gave $2,000; Kwik Trip executive Don Zietlow, who gave $2,000; and Menard's founder and owner John Menard, who gave $2,800. Tiffany also received over $98,000 in donations from WinRed.
In past filings, Tiffany has recorded donations from Stormy Kromer CEO Robert J. Jacquart; John M. Tonne, from owner of Paul Bunyan's Cook Shanty in Minocqua; John E. Link, owner of Jack Link's Protein Snacks in Minong. Tiffany also received a large donation from Richard and Elizabeth Uihlein, the leaders of the Pleasant Prairie packaging company Uline Corporation. The Uihleins have invested heavily in conservative politics. Richard Uihlein is a descendant of the Schlitz beer empire, according to the New York Times.
Tiffany was the only candidate to file with the FEC in October, reporting over $240,000 raised in the first month of his campaign.
Tiffany, 62, has served as a state senator since 2013 and spent two decades running Wilderness Cruises on the Willow Flowage. He was the first to declare his candidacy in the 7th District.
Church, 30, is a wounded Army veteran and after his deployment spent six years working for U.S. Sen. Ron Johnson, R-Wis.
The limit for contributions to campaigns for the special election is $2,800 for the primary and $2,800 for the special election, according to the FEC. Donors will also be able to commit money to a campaign in the district at the end of 2020 for the general election.
One source of spending for the candidates has been television commercials. Church has produced several, with his latest showing him shooting a shotgun while talking about how Democrats were trying to impeach Trump "one day after he was elected."
Tiffany has also paid for TV commercials, including one showing him shoveling manure in a dairy barn that aired on Jan. 12, during the Green Bay Packers' playoff game against Seattle.
Democratic candidates Zunker brought in over $145,000 in contributions since her candidacy announcement last fall. Most of her contributions came from Wisconsin residents, though some donations came in from California, Arizona, Oklahoma, Pennsylvania and Colorado, according to donation records.
Notable among her donors were the host of liberal news site Crooked Media, Erin Ryan, who gave $400; and Lynde Bradley Uihlein, a Wisconsin philanthropist, liberal donor and heir to the Schlitz beer fortune, who gave $5,600. Lynde Uhliein is a cousin of Richard Uihlein, according to thebadgerproject.org.
Zunker also received over $56,00 in donations from ActBlue, a technology company that helps gather donations for Democratic candidates.
Zunker, 39, is the president of the Wausau School Board and an associate justice for the Ho-Chunk Nation Supreme Court.
Dale, 71, previously conducted research on slaughter and meat processing and worked as a union organizer. He ran for the 7th Congressional District seat in 2014 as a Green Party member, but lost to Duffy.
The 7th Congressional District is the largest geographically in Wisconsin, spanning 21 whole counties and covering portions of five others. The district is home to over 710,000 people, according to census data.
Contact Laura Schulte at 715-496-4088 or leschulte@gannett.com. Follow her on Twitter @schultelaura.
The Democratic candidates for Wisconsin's 7th Congressional District, Lawrence Dale (left) and Tricia Zunker.

Trump took best punch

Información de publicación: Asbury Park Press ; Asbury Park, N.J. [Asbury Park, N.J]. 09 Feb 2020: C.3.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/trump-took-best-punch/docview/2352380866/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=unknown&amp;atitle=Trump+took+best+punch%3A+Democrats+threw+everything+they+had+at+him%2C+but+he%27s+still+standing&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=C.3&amp;date=2020-02-09&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Asbury+Park+Press&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: WASHINGTON – Democrats' drive to impeach and remove President Trump was destined to fail. But more than fail, it has backfired on them — strengthening Trump for the 2020 campaign and increasing his odds of winning a second term.
First, impeachment appears to have raised Trump's approval rating to the highest point of his presidency. In mid-October, just before the House impeachment hearings began, Trump's Gallup approval rating was just 39% — a few points above his all-time low. This week, as his Senate trial wound up, Gallup reported that Trump's approval has risen a 10 full points to 49% — his all-time personal best. The number of Americans who want Trump removed has plummeted. In October, a 52% majority of Americans supported his removal, today a 52% majority opposes it. For Democrats, this is the very definition of failure.
Far from advancing their case for removing Trump, Democrats have convinced more Americans that he deserves a second term. Before the 2018 midterms that put Democrats in control of the House, just 41% of the country said Trump should be reelected; today, after the Democratic House's failed impeachment effort, 50% want to give him four more years. Since impeachment began, Trump's standing with the voters has improved by almost every measure.
Second, impeachment has energized Trump's base. According to Gallup, the president's approval among Republicans is now a record 94% — up six percentage points since January. The more Democrats tried to take him down, the more Republicans have united behind the president.
Third, the failure of their impeachment drive has dispirited the Democratic base. An Associated Press poll finds that just 33% of Democrats are excited about the 2020 election. At the Iowa caucuses, where Democratic voters had their first chance to show their enthusiasm for replacing Trump, turnout was a dismal 170,000 — a 30% decline from 2008, when 240,000 Iowans turned out to give Barack Obama his first presidential primary victory.
Fourth, impeachment has put moderate House Democrats in grave peril. A New York Times/Sienna College poll recently found that almost two-thirds of voters in six battleground states who cast their ballots for Trump in 2016, but then voted for House Democrats in 2018, plan to back Trump again in 2020. That's bad news for the 31 House Democrats elected in Trump districts in the midterms. How many people are going to vote to give Trump a second term and vote for the Democrats who tried to take away their right to do so? Not many.
Fifth, impeachment forced Democrats to unlock the legislative floodgates and give Trump major victories. Democrats knew that voters saw them focusing on impeachment at the expense of getting things done, so as they voted to approve articles of impeachment, they also voted to approve the U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement, Trump's tax bill that repealed three Obamacare taxes, and Trump's $738 billion defense spending bill that created his Space Force and enacted his parental leave policy for federal workers, without restricting his use of defense dollars to build a border wall. The effect was the opposite of what Democrats intended, creating the impression that while Democrats were busy impeaching, Trump was busy governing.
Finally, impeachment has helped Trump raise an enormous war chest. In the last three months of 2019 — the period during which the House conducted its impeachment inquiry — Trump raised $46 million, giving him $102.7 million in the bank. The Senate trial will likely have a similar impact on his fundraising in the first quarter of 2020. Impeachment not only energized Republican voters, it has energized Republican donors.
And the Democrats' self-inflicted wounds keep coming. During Trump's State of the Union address, the House impeachment managers sat together in the chamber, sullen and stone-faced. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., broke protocol and refused to utter the traditional words of introduction — "it is my high honor and distinct privilege to introduce the president of the United States" — and then dramatically tore up Trump's address on national television when he concluded. The image Democrats projected to the country was that of a bunch of sore losers.
Trump now goes into the 2020 election strengthened and emboldened — the first president in U.S. history to carry an impeachment acquittal into a general election. For three years, Democrats threw everything they had at Trump. They accused him of bribery, extortion, campaign finance violations, obstruction of justice, obstruction of Congress, abuse of power, conspiracy and even treason. Three years later, he's still standing — and thanks to impeachment, he may still be standing after the dust settles in November.
Marc A. Thiessen is a Washington Post columnist.
Marc A. Thiessen
Columnist
Marc A. Thiessen
Columnist

____________________________________________________________

Constitution is working in Trump era, even as the press comes under attack

Información de publicación: The Poughkeepsie Journal ; Poughkeepsie, N.Y. [Poughkeepsie, N.Y]. 09 Feb 2020: A.2.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/constitution-is-working-trump-era-even-as-press/docview/2352380030/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Constitution+is+working+in+Trump+era%2C+even+as+the+press+comes+under+attack&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.2&amp;date=2020-02-09&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Poughkeepsie+Journal&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: When your country is mired in the middle of a nasty political and constitutional battle and your leader is crazily tweeting 142 times in one day, it is difficult to not be depressed – and alarmed. Counselors call it "Trump anxiety disorder." They are seeing more and more patients with psychological issues from President Trump's rhetoric and policies.
Many people say they just can't watch the news. That's never good in a self-governing society.
"There is a fear of the world ending," says Elisabeth LaMotte, the founder of a counseling DC Counseling & Psychotherapy Center in Washington, D.C. "It's very disorienting and constantly unsettling."
I can't make the chaos go away – in fact, I suffer from it – but I can assert that what is happening now is exactly how the framers of the Constitution meant it to be. The parts of the constitutional puzzle are actually working.
We can nitpick on strategies by either side, debate emerging questions about media behavior, and bemoan the outcomes. But the system is, for now, holding. The democratic world is not falling apart ... yet. And, no surprise, the media is in the middle of the unfolding drama of impeachment.
Back in 1787, the framers knew that a president might attempt "high crimes and misdemeanors," so they established a careful constitutional process of impeachment, as we have seen. Four years later, in 1791, they added 10 amendments, a Bill of Rights.
The First Amendment was to protect citizens in their ability to squawk to their heart's content about government. And they clearly protected the press – the media in the middle – understanding that the party in power, given the chance, would try to stifle and censor its opposition. The press needed shielding so it could report to the citizens without interference from government. So here we are – the press reporting and the authorities trying to discredit the reporting.
I called Buddy Stein, a Pulitzer Prize-winning New York City editorial writer who has been a keen observer of the press for many years and a journalism professor. Stein was not as optimistic as I about all being hunky-dory. He wondered about the House of Representatives' strategy to rush through impeachment, although he understood that if the Senate or the president challenged the attempt to seek witnesses and documents, impeachment might grind to a dangerous halt.
But when it came to the press, Stein was more gleeful, saying "the exposés, the accountability reporting" have been "absolutely superb." For a year or more, Stein points out, the New York Times, Washington Post, and Wall Street Journal have been "carrying a heavy load and doing it very well."
The story actually began in September last year when the Washington Post revealed pressure on the president of Ukraine to mount an investigation of the Bidens or get no American financial aid. "We're reliably told that the president has a venal agenda: He is attempting to force Mr. Zelensky to intervene in the 2020 U.S. presidential election." The startling words came in an editorial!
Editorials usually express the opinion of the publication's management; they don't break news or reveal new facts. But all the press tools have been on display in this historical episode – editorials, breaking news, anonymous sources, leaked documents and testimony, revealing and damning books, TV interviews that startle, wall-to-wall coverage of events.
On Sept. 9, the intelligence community's inspector general said privately he received a complaint of "urgent concern" about the President's infamous phone call. On Sept. 18, using unnamed sources, the Post revealed to an astounded nation that a whistleblower had given damning information to the government. The media in the middle! A mad rush of exposés pushed the story furiously forward.
Predictably, the president called it "fake news," his pet phrase for anything that criticizes him. And that is why the First Amendment becomes so important. The press is still the crucible, the block to avoiding a leap to authoritarianism. Just watch the behaviors we are seeing every day.
CNN's Manu Raju recently asked Arizona Sen. Martha McSally, "Should the Senate consider new evidence as part of the impeachment trial?" A straightforward question. Granted, she was walking down a hall and it was a yelled-out query. But her answer speaks volumes. "I won't answer you. You are a liberal hack."
A classic response. The press is the liberal enemy. It's an old cry, dating back at least to when Richard Nixon in 1969 sent his vice president, Spiro Agnew (he later pleaded guilty to accepting bribes), on a cross-country, televised tour to attack "the liberal eastern establishment" press. If you oppose us, you must be "liberal."
Stein calls such charges "baloney," adding, "I come from he left. I don't see a monolith. There are all sorts of reasons to be critical of the big media for being insufficiently critical or skeptical on so many issues." But being liberal is just trite and wrong-headed. Stein said he thought National Public Radio – publicly funded in part by the government – has been particularly namby-pamby in its Ukraine coverage.
And yet, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, under great pressure to talk about the scandal, recently was interviewed by an NPR reporter who pushed him on Ukraine ... of course. He ended up screaming at her, claiming she broke their interview agreement rules. "Another example of how unhinged the media has become in its quest to hurt" the president, he declared.
NPR's Mary Louise Kelly responded: "Journalists don't sit down with senior government officials in the service of scoring political points. We do it in the service of asking tough questions." And that's what the press does at its constitutional best: it's in the middle, contrarians, gadflies, pains in the butt, poking holes, digging into the swamp.
Nonetheless, the president applauded Pompeo's harsh words, saying with a big smile: "I think you did a good job on her, actually." The State Department then threw an NPR reporter off a press plane as punishment, arguably an unconstitutional move.
Trump's language is remarkably similar to his threatening talk about the press at rallies, words that have made reporters literally fear for their safety. The framers of the Constitution envisioned tension and an adversarial relationship, but not the bullying that this President has consistently shown.
But the hostility goes on. During the impeachment hearing, the Republican majority cordoned off the press, literally, and strictly controlled cameras. It was Soviet Union-like. New Mexico Sen. Martin Heinrich complained: "To place limitations on the press is to place limitations on the American people's ability to learn about the character and conduct of their elected leaders."
The last formal White House press briefing was March 19! The president is threatening to sue to stop publication of John Bolton's book. Last week he banned CNN from an annual TV anchors briefing.
The press belongs in the middle – reporting back to the citizenry, not being roped off. And our goal – as the Constitution insisted – is simple: keep the president's hands off the press.
Rob Miraldi's writings on the First Amendment have won numerous state and national awards. He teaches journalism at SUNY Paltz. Twitter @miral98 and email miral98@aol.com.
First Freedom
Rob Miraldi
Guest columnist

Black journalists have excelled in breaking barriers

Información de publicación: Rochester Democrat and Chronicle ; Rochester, N.Y. [Rochester, N.Y]. 09 Feb 2020: A.2.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/black-journalists-have-excelled-breaking-barriers/docview/2352378912/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Black+journalists+have+excelled+in+breaking+barriers&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.2&amp;date=2020-02-09&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Rochester+Democrat+and+Chronicle&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: By the time I arrived at the now defunct Times-Union in 1980, there were people of color in the newsroom, though certainly not many. Most of the reporters and all of the editors were white, like me.
When she died, Gwen Ifill received tribute after tribute for her work as a journalist.
Her portrait, released on the eve of Black History Month, is even on a Forever Stamp now as part of the U.S. Postal Service's Black Heritage series. She joins the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., Jackie Robinson, Ella Fitzgerald and other luminaries in the series.
At the time of her death in 2016 at age 61, Ifill was a news anchor on PBS. Before that she had been a political reporter at the New York Times and other newspapers. Most impressively, she rose to the top in a profession that was predominately male and white.
There have been journalists like Ifill in Rochester, as well — the pioneers and ground-breakers who made their way against real odds.
Certainly we think of Frederick Douglass, the former slave who is perhaps the most prominent journalist to have lived here.
Later, there was Howard Coles, an African American born near Caledonia, Livingston County, who for years edited The Voice (later The Frederick Douglass Voice), reporting on a black community that was often ignored by the mainstream press. Earl Caldwell was with the Democrat and Chronicle in the 1960s and went on to be a force in New York City journalism.
By the time I arrived at the now defunct Times-Union in 1980, there were people of color in the newsroom, though certainly not many. Most of the reporters and all of the editors were white, like me.
My desk mate, Jim Mitchell, was African American, as was Dolores Orman, who covered crime and courts. Jim went on to other papers fairly soon. Dolores, who is retired and still living in Rochester, was valued in the newsroom for her memory, her contacts, her persistence.
A native of Kansas, Dolores graduated from the University of Kansas and then joined the Herald and News Tribune in Duluth, Minnesota, as that paper's first black reporter. She came to the Times-Union in 1968, becoming one of that paper's first black reporters.
"I felt at home," Dolores says, "welcomed and accepted by whites, both in the newsroom and in the community." At the same time, she remembers black staff members advocating for more black editors and black reporters to ensure that there would be "truly fair and full coverage of the Rochester area."
Over the years, I was lucky to work with other colleagues who were African American. But certainly, the number of African American reporters and editors, though it increased over the years, did not reflect the diversity of the community. I was once in management, so a portion of the blame for this gap falls upon me.
Last year, some of the black journalists working at the Democrat and Chronicle wrote about what inspired them to become reporters and editors.
James Johnson, who has covered high school sports for years, remembered a summer internship at the Times-Union while he was a student at Edison Tech. (He recently wrote more about that in a call for applications to the Democrat and Chronicle's summer academy for students interested in journalism.)
Cynthia Benjamin, the community content editor, wrote with gratitude about how her career in journalism had fulfilled a childhood dream.
But Cynthia also recalled a time in Rochester when she was spat upon, and a time when the N-word was written on her car. (She tweeted about that and was overwhelmed by kind and supportive reactions from people of all races.)
Cynthia and some of the other people mentioned here are members of the Rochester Association of Black Journalists, which was named the 2019 winner of the Chapter of the Year award from the National Association of Black Journalists.
It's not surprising that the group, which includes members from a variety of media, was honored, given the talent in Rochester.
Like Gwen Ifill, all of the journalists have been fighting the good fight, both inspiring and informing. We owe them thanks.
Sad update Mary Gooley, a longtime advocate for people with hemophilia who is on this column's list of Remarkable Rochesterians, died on Dec. 30, 2019. She was 94.
This coverage is only possible with support from our readers. Sign up today for a digital subscription.

Jim Memmott

James M. McCuller (1940-1992): The executive director of the Rochester anti-poverty agency Action for a Better Community for 25 years, the Arkansas native was hailed at the time of his death as a "gallant crusader" for the poor and members of minority communities. A graduate of what is now Central State University in Ohio, he was also a board member of the Rochester Health Network and a member of the Black Political Caucus, as well as an organizer of several groups that advocated non-violent solutions to social problems.

Looking for a chance to excel

Autor: de León, Concepción. 

Información de publicación: Chicago Tribune ; Chicago, Ill. [Chicago, Ill]. 09 Feb 2020: 4.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/looking-chance-excel/docview/2352364778/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Looking+for+a+chance+to+excel%3A+Abi+Dare+confronts+%27dreams+and+intelligence+that+we+kill%27+when+girls+must+work+instead+of+learn&amp;author=de+Le%C3%B3n%2C+Concepci%C3%B3n&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=4&amp;date=2020-02-09&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Chicago+Tribune&amp;issn=1085-6706&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Achicagotribune_

Texto completo: 'The Girl With the Louding Voice'
By Abi Dare, Dutton, 384 pages, $26
The inspiration for Abi Dare's first book struck when one of her daughters, then 8, didn't feel like unloading the dishwasher.
Dare, who lives in London but grew up in Lagos, told her that there were girls her age in Nigeria who did housework for a living.
"She stopped and said, 'But what do you mean, Mom? Do you mean like working, like doing the day's work in an office, and they get paid? That's really cool they get paid. Can I get paid?' " Dare recalled in an interview.
The conversation gave her a new perspective on something that was common among middle-class families like the one in which she was raised: employing young girls as so-called housemaids.
That night, Dare started doing research. She searched "housemaids in Nigeria" and came across articles detailing the violence, mistreatment and low or nonexistent pay that are often part of their working conditions. One account of a 13-year-old girl whose employer scalded her with boiling water stood out. "The report was harrowing," Dare said, "but what also made it quite painful for me was that her face was a blur, and it just felt like another statistic to report."
Her debut novel, "The Girl With the Louding Voice," out last Tuesday, gives voice to one such girl. Raised in poverty, 14-year-old Adunni finds work as a housemaid for a rich Lagos family, enduring abuse and exploitation while she yearns to go to school.
Dare, 38, who works in project management for an academic publisher, talked about the novel's focus on education, writing about class in Nigeria and how she tried to find Adunni's voice. These are edited excerpts from the conversation.
Q: Why did you decide to write the book in broken English?
A: I felt that I needed to break her English down and break myself down in the process to understand her, so that she could be understood by anyone else who's reading it. When I was writing it, I did not think it would get published. So I was really telling myself a story.
Many of the maids I knew or that my husband knew, they didn't speak good English. I found that I couldn't use any metaphors that I was used to, and I found myself constantly thinking of the character and saying, "How would she say it?"
Q: How did you tap into that? What were some of the challenges of writing in that voice?
A: Nigerians speak something called pidgin English, and I knew I didn't want to write in pidgin English because even the very educated people speak pidgin English. So I knew it wasn't going to be that. I wanted it to be nonstandard English, whatever that meant. I thought by doing that, I could make it Adunni's. It could be her own English, so to speak.
So the first thing I did was to watch as many Nigerian movies as I could. I was watching these movies of people in the market, and they would describe the political situation in Nigeria with broken English but with frustration at not being able to get out what they're trying to say. I watched a lot of that.
I looked through Alice Walker's "The Color Purple" over and over again. I know it's not the same, but it was very helpful to see how Alice Walker did that, because I thought, "OK, she's very educated, so how did she get that out?"
Q: Despite the broken English, you can really tell how bright and feisty Adunni is.
A: I wanted to explore the amount of talent and dreams and intelligence that we kill and waste when we don't allow these girls to go to school, when we hire these young girls and get them to work. I wanted to show that this was a girl who dreamed. She is more than just a girl that needs to be up at 4 in the morning. She's intelligent, and if she was given a chance, and other young girls in the world, they will shine and they will thrive. I really wanted her to come across as someone that was more than a girl that could not speak English. And this is why she makes that realization somewhere in the book that, look, it's just a language. It's not a measure of intelligence.
Q: When Adunni arrives in Lagos, she has a hard time understanding class -- she asks why she can't talk to Big Madam, her employer, directly. I wonder if you could speak a little bit about that class distinction and why she might not have been attuned to what it meant.
A: She's from a village where everyone is kind of the same class. Then once she gets to Lagos and sees this wealth, I mean, that was a huge chasm. There's a huge divide between the poor and the rich, and I saw that growing up. The people that work for families would be treated as if they were second-class citizens. She couldn't understand it because she'd only known a society where everyone could speak to everyone. It's just very strange to her. And also her personality as well. She loves to speak and she loves to be heard.
Q: You used a fictional book called "The Big Book of Nigerian Facts" in the novel, and I found it interesting that Adunni has lived in Nigeria her whole life, but she was learning about it from a book. What do you make of the Nigeria that she knows versus the Nigeria that she's learning about in this big book?
A: Nigeria is such a huge country that I have never even been to many of the states. There are things about Nigeria that I'm still discovering, and that's just the vastness of the country. I wanted to reflect that, especially for a character like Adunni that has come from not being fully educated and being shielded by her village.
Q: The book hinges on her desire for an education; it's what drives her throughout the book. Can you talk about that particular choice?
A: I was about 14 or 15, I was just discovering that I was pretty, and I was getting a bit of attention, having crushes on guys. And one evening, I was going to meet up with one guy -- I was meeting him downstairs. We had agreed to meet at a certain time, at 8 o'clock.
I took the dustbin, and I pretended to go empty the trash, and as I was going downstairs, my mother walked behind me. I was like, "Why is she coming with me?" And so I got downstairs, and then she said, "Come here. Let's have a chat." She said, "I know you're not going to empty the trash. I know you're going to meet a guy."
She said, "Listen, all of this is going to pass away. You're going to leave. You're going to get older. Beauty will fade. Everything will fade, but the only thing that will not fade is your intelligence, and what is in your head, your education."
She also said to me, as I got older: "The only reason why I've been able to educate yourself and your brother is because I invested in my own education and made something out of my life. If I hadn't, you both would not be where you are today."
That really resonated with me, the importance of education. I'd seen it in my mother's life, and then I grasped onto it myself. I think that conversation that night was life-changing for me. In Nigeria as a whole, education is very valued, but sadly there's not enough of it to go around because of poverty. And so I wanted to drive that home.
A lot of people are very educated and not all of them get jobs, especially in this day and age. But for someone like Adunni, education was the first step to anything else. I think that it is an essential foundation for any life, especially for girls.
CAPTION: Photo: Abi Dare's debut novel, "The Girl With the Louding Voice," gives voice to a 14-year-old girl who endures abuse and exploitation, and yearns to attend school, as a housemaid for a rich Lagos family. ELLIE SMITH/THE NEW YORK TIMES ; Photo: 'The Girl With the Louding Voice' ; By Abi Dare, Dutton, 384 pages, $26
CREDIT: By Concepción de León, The New York Times
