Her words create a stir; Harvey att'y suggests vics bear some responsibility

Autor: Crane-Newman, Molly; McShane, Larry. 

Información de publicación: New York Daily News ; New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]. 08 Feb 2020: CS.14.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/her-words-create-stir-harvey-atty-suggests-vics/docview/2352285294/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Her+words+create+a+stir%3B+Harvey+att%27y+suggests+vics+bear+some+responsibility&amp;author=Crane-Newman%2C+Molly%3BMcShane%2C+Larry&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=CS.14&amp;date=2020-02-08&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=New+York+Daily+News&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: Harvey Weinstein's lead defense lawyer, in an lengthy interview made public Friday, appeared to lay some of the blame for sexual assaults against women on the victims.
Assistant District Attorney Joan Illuzzi complained loudly in court about the comments made by Donna Rotunno in a New York Times podcast recorded last week. The Weinstein lawyer, who has represented a number of #MeToo defendants, replied quickly when asked during the interview if she was ever sexually assaulted.
"I have not, I have not, because I would never put myself in that position," said Rotunno. "I've always made choices from college age on where I never drank too much, never went home with someone I didn't know. I just never put myself in any vulnerable circumstance. Never."
Illuzzi was also irked by a Rotunno reference to America's "society of celebrity victimhood status ... a society where women don't have to take any responsibility for their actions." Illuzzi griped that Rotunno's sitdown with the Times flew in the face of instructions by Manhattan Supreme Court Justice James Burke for both sides to avoid the media during the trial.
"She's calling our witnesses liars and 'celebrity victimhood status,' and it is completely in contradiction to your order," Illuzzi told Burke. "So we are asking for you to order the defense to cease and desist any discussion about this case in public."
Rotunno insisted she had not spoken with any reporters since the trial began, and only learned about the podcast's airing in a Friday morning phone call from a friend.
"That was taped a long time ago," she claimed. "I have not spoken to anyone in the media. Have not spoken to anyone since we started this case. That was taped a while ago, and I did not speak about any witness individually."
The Times, in a statement released Friday, said Rotunno sat for the interview last week and was aware in advance of the air date. Burke imposed no sanctions after hearing from both sides.
Weinstein, 67, appeared to fall asleep at times during the morning testimony, his head drooping down as his lawyers put on their case. The defendant also removed his blazer at one point as a memory expert became the second defense witness called by Rotunno.
The high-profile trial was winding down, with the prosecution resting its case Thursday after calling 27 witnesses against Weinstein - including six accusers who graphically detailed about their unwanted sexual encounters with the Oscar-winning producer.

A CHANCE AT FREEDOM

Autor: HANNAN ADELYNORTHJERSEYCOM. 

Información de publicación: Home News Tribune ; East Brunswick, N.J. [East Brunswick, N.J]. 08 Feb 2020: A.6.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/chance-at-freedom/docview/2352279428/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=A+CHANCE+AT+FREEDOM%3A+AT+SETON+HALL%2C+A+QUEST+TO+GET+THE+INNOCENT+OUT+OF+JAIL&amp;author=HANNAN+ADELYNORTHJERSEYCOM&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.6&amp;date=2020-02-08&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Home+News+Tribune&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: For nearly a decade, Lesley and D. Michael Risinger pored over transcripts, interviewed witnesses, consulted firearms experts and argued in courtrooms, with help of a team of Seton Hall law students.
Their goal: Free two men they believed were wrongly convicted for a double murder in Camden a quarter-century ago.
That chance at freedom came Dec. 26, when a New Jersey appeals court overturned the convictions and ordered a new trial for Kevin Baker and Shawn Washington, who were found guilty of the killings and locked away in state prison in 1996.
For the husband-and-wife legal team who run the Last Resort Exoneration Project at Seton Hall Law School in Newark, it was a hard-fought first victory after years of work to make the justice system face up to its own flaws.
"There's nothing worse than being locked up for something you didn't do, especially if it's a long sentence," said Lesley Risinger, who co-founded the program in 2011 and serves as director. "When someone is locked up, possibly for life, for a crime they had nothing to do with, it's a thing you get inside you and that you feel is intolerable."
The Exoneration Project is driven by a key premise — that the criminal justice system makes mistakes and may send people to prison for crimes they did not commit. An estimated 1% to 5% of those in prison have been wrongfully convicted, according to a report last year ordered by New Jersey Attorney General Gurbir Grewal.
Assuming a 1% rate of wrongful conviction in New Jersey, nearly 200 of those currently in a state prison population of about 19,500 people are innocent. Yet there have been only 37 overturned convictions in the state since 1989, the report said.
'Total failure of the defense' Lesley Risinger first got involved in cases of the wrongfully accused nearly 30 years ago, when she helped her mother, an attorney, appeal the conviction of Luis Kevin Rojas of Weehawken. Rojas, 18 at the time of the alleged crime, had been found guilty of a fatal shooting in 1990, but the case was marred by mistaken identity and missing eyewitness testimony, his attorneys successfully argued. He was freed after a retrial in 1998.
Risinger later represented Fernando Bermudez, who was convicted in a 1991 Manhattan murder, but the case was based on perjured testimony, Risinger argued. In 2009, a judge freed Bermudez after 18 years in prison.
In 2011, the Risingers launched the Last Resort Exoneration Project and got many letters from prisoners claiming innocence and looking for help. With help from law students, they vet cases for evidence that could prove a conviction was improper.
The application from Kevin Baker, one of the two convicts in the Camden case, was compelling.
"It cried out for attention simply based on the weakness of the evidence and the total failure of the defense to present a defense," said Lesley Risinger, 62, a former adjunct professor who graduated from the law school in 2003.
The case rested on testimony from a single witness who was high on crack at the time of the shooting and whose story was so shaky that defense lawyers thought it wouldn't be believed, Risinger said. The state called six witnesses during the two-day trial, while the defense called none, court records show.
The proceedings ended in a guilty verdict and life sentences with no chance of parole for 60 years. John Wynne, an assistant Camden County prosecutor on the case, told The New York Times in 1996 that even he was surprised by the verdict.
"We had to do the investigation that should have been done then," said D. Michael Risinger, 72, the associate director of the Exoneration Project.
Last month, a state appeals court finally agreed, ordering a new trial. The court ruled that additional evidence not presented at the time "probably would have changed the jury's verdict." Jurors never heard a recording of Baker's 911 call or a forensics analysis showing that the shooting could not have happened as the witness described, the court found.
Baker and Washington, who is represented by Lawrence Lustberg, an attorney with Gibbons P.C. in Newark, remain in state prison in Trenton waiting to find out whether the Camden County prosecutor will seek a new trial.
The Risingers hope a conviction review unit created by the New Jersey Attorney General's Office last year will end the case and the Prosecutor's Office will determine that pursuing it "would be fruitless and unjust."
In a statement, Grewal said his office and Camden prosecutors are "committed to pursuing the just result in each and every case.
"We are actively reviewing this case, including the trial evidence and the extensive appellate and post-conviction proceedings that have taken place over the past 25 years," Grewal said.
A passion for the work The Last Resort Exoneration Project is similar to "innocence projects" that rely on DNA to prove that individuals did not commit crimes of which they were accused.
But the Risingers have taken an even more difficult route, choosing cases that lack DNA evidence but where other facts show the defendants did not receive a fair trial. They said they closely review applications to see where there's a strong legal case to prove innocence.
The Baker case is the Exoneration Project's first overturned conviction and required extensive litigation, expert analysis and hundreds of legal exhibits. The Risingers said they have also given close consideration to at least a dozen more cases.
About half a dozen law school students volunteer with the program each year. Over nine years, about a dozen worked on the Camden case, studying case files, reviewing trial documents and giving feedback on oral arguments.
They include Renee Mariotti, a part-time law student from New York City who chose Seton Hall Law in part for the chance to work at the Exoneration Project. Her interest came after listening to podcasts about wrongful convictions, in particular the Baltimore murder case of Adnan Syed made famous in the podcast "Serial."
"These are men who have been imprisoned for, coming up on 25 years, crimes they did not commit," Mariotti said of Baker and Washington. "It's nice to see the law working in what feels like the right way in this case. That's not always the outcome."
Amy Cuzzolino, a Bloomfield native who graduated in 2016, helped review applications to find viable legal cases. Her work gave her more insight into how the justice system works — and fails, she said.
"I didn't come away with a sense that the system is bad because of bad actors in it. It's more a question of inefficiency and limited resources. There are a lot of people who want to do the right thing but don't know how," said Cuzzolino, who is studying for an advanced degree in international law.
The Risingers, who live in Kearny, don't take a salary for their work. Private donations to the program pay for expenses like buying transcripts and consulting experts.
Michael Risinger, who worked on civil rights cases involving wrongful police shootings in the '70s and '80s, said he has devoted his career to making sure the legal system is accurate, especially in criminal cases. The former Seton Hall law professor served on the New Jersey Supreme Court's Committee on Evidence for 25 years.
He and his wife, who married in 2004 and have six children from previous marriages, see their work with the Exoneration Project as a calling, he said.
"We have sufficient money. We live very frugally, and we don't have ambitions to take grand tours or anything," he said. "We'd rather do this."

Mitsu Yasukawa/Northjersey.com

1970 hit 'Love Story' is back in theaters. Go see it

Autor: Beckerman, Jim. 

Información de publicación: Asbury Park Press ; Asbury Park, N.J. [Asbury Park, N.J]. 08 Feb 2020: C.2.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/1970-hit-love-story-is-back-theaters-go-see/docview/2352279356/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=1970+hit+%27Love+Story%27+is+back+in+theaters.+Go+see+it&amp;author=Beckerman%2C+Jim&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=C.2&amp;date=2020-02-08&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Asbury+Park+Press&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: Loving "Love Story" means never having to say you're sorry you love "Love Story."
No apologies. No denials. No remarks like, "I know it's corny, but..."
Go on, weep. Let it out.
Bawl into your popcorn as lovely Ali McGraw, the spirited Radcliffe music major, says her deathbed farewell to Ryan O'Neal, the handsome Harvard preppie. "Love means never having to say you're sorry," she tells him — in the movie, on the poster, and in that mystic land where pop culture clichés live forever.
What can you say about an iconic movie that is coming back to theaters for Valentine's Day week?
That it grossed $106 million? That it was a surprise mega-hit in 1970? That it divided the nation between those who wept and those who snickered?
That you can see it at 1 p.m. Sunday and 7 p.m. Wednesday at AMC Theaters across the country?
In a way, "Love Story" was an early broadside in the culture wars. It pit the critical elites, who mocked it in print and on TV, against Mr. and Mrs. Average American, who thought it was just swell. "You ain't human if you don't cry at that movie," said a character, defensively, in a TV sitcom of the era.
"I think both of those arguments — those who were moved to tears, and those who thought it was sappy and sentimental — have a point," said TCM host Ben Mankiewicz, who will be introducing the screenings, sponsored by Fathom Events, Turner Classic Movies and Paramount Pictures.
Among the things critics cackled over in 1970: the malady (never named) that doomed Jenny Cavalieri dies from. What kind of illness makes you even prettier on your deathbed? "Old Movie Disease" was the diagnosis of Mad Magazine.
"I suspect cancer makes people uncomfortable," Mankiewicz said. "That certainly would not be the case if they remade it today."
As for the heroine who becomes more beautiful as she dies — well, in operas, the heroine sings as she dies. "I think if the doctors accept it, and Ryan O'Neal accepts it, we accept it," Mankiewicz said. "We just buy what the characters in the movie accept. That's one of the beautiful things about movies."
As "Love Story" turned into the No. 1 grosser of 1970, and the book became the top-selling work of fiction the same year — the first time a novelization made it to the New York Times bestseller lists — it propelled writer Erich Segal, a Harvard classics professor and sometime movie writer ("Yellow Submarine") to fame as the culture warrior of the squares.
A key moment of the era was a January 1971 Dick Cavett Show, when Segal shared the stage with snide highbrow critic John Simon and rocker Little Richard.
"I have read and reread ["Love Story"] many times," Segal told Cavett modestly. "I am always moved."
Simon called Segal a "knave." Segal called Simon an "effete litterateur."
It was a momentous clash — so much so that later, commentators offered different versions, "Rashomon"-style.
To sci-fi writer Harlan Ellison (he had a TV column at the time), it was nothing less than a pivotal moment in Western civilization. Simon, the heroic critic, was the only thing standing between us and the Visigoths.
"Debasing emotions like love and recognition of one's own mortality," Ellison said, is "the cheap trick of panhandlers, flack merchants, con men."
"I am not bought that cheaply," said Ellison, grandly. "And neither are my tears."
Meanwhile, rock critic Greil Marcus saw both Simon and Segal as frauds. "Little Richard was the only artist on the stage that night," he wrote in his book "Mystery Train."
In the end, civilization survived. So did "Love Story." The famous theme music by Francis Lai became a favorite piece of elevator music, in versions by Ferrante & Teicher, Mantovani, and Andy Williams. There was a sequel, "Oliver's Story."
"This is a story of capitalism, as much as it is a love story," Mankiewicz said. "The people who made it were looking to make money."
Harvard freshmen, it is said, are still shown "Love Story" as part of orientation week. They cackle, hoot, and send it up, a la "Rocky Horror Picture Show."
They have every right. Harvard is not only the setting of the film but also the inspiration for the characters. Oliver is said to be a mashup of Harvard graduates Al Gore and Tommy Lee Jones; Jones made his film debut in the movie.
"Segal went to Harvard and he knew those guys," Mankiewicz said. "It makes sense that he would craft the character of Oliver out of the Harvard students that he knew."
For the rest of us, "Love Story" is a movie that can still move, Mankiewicz said. In a battle between the head and heart, most moviegoers will go for the tear ducts.
"If what you really want is to immerse yourself in a cinematic experience, I think being moved is going to win," he said.

Ryan O'Neal and Ali MacGraw in a scene from "Love Story."
Paramount Pictures

A modest proposal for Iowa

Información de publicación: Press - Citizen ; Iowa City, Iowa [Iowa City, Iowa]. 08 Feb 2020: A.6.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/modest-proposal-iowa/docview/2352279054/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=A+modest+proposal+for+Iowa&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.6&amp;date=2020-02-08&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Press+-+Citizen&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anorthcentralnews_

Texto completo: Lately, it has been exceedingly hard to miss that the Iowa Caucuses aren't, not to put too fine a point on it, universally popular.
Those who believe Iowa shouldn't go first point to the overwhelming whiteness of the state, the overwhelming rurality of the state, the overwhelmingly older population of the state. Those who dislike the caucus format argue that the system is anti-democratic, a form of voter suppression against those with children or jobs or disabilities; a deterrent to those who do not wish to publicly share their vote and a logistical nightmare of finding locations to hold thousands of arguing activists.
Iowa is first because state law requires that we caucus before any other nominating process. New Hampshire is second because its state law says it must primary first, and Iowa doesn't primary — the only place — if you believe the wailing from opinion pieces in national media. If Iowa switches from a caucus to a primary, New Hampshire's primary has to move earlier so that it remains first. We could get caught up in a race of leapfrog, each state bouncing backward a week until the next primary takes place before the previous election. Or until the Supreme Court decides who gets to be very most firstest.
So, here we are: Iowa the first nominating contest, New Hampshire the first primary, and no one happy. Well, some people happy. In what other state are endorsements from local officials and activists so dearly sought after — or do nationally recognized politicians regularly endorse in local races? In what other state can a tiny diner be a nationally recognized, must-see political destination? What other snow-bound state boasts hotels stuffed with journalists and prominent national figures for the entire month of January?
And with out-of-staters howling for the end of Iowa's primacy in the rudest possible terms, well, we aren't likely to see the end of the First-In-The-Nation Caucus any time soon. We Iowans tend to dig in when outsiders try to tell us what to do, and we know a good deal when we see one.
Dear reader, we believe that we Iowans could find ways to deliberate with our neighbors in crowded gyms without presidential caucuses, but we know that the boost to our state's economy, national profile, and pet issues would be terrible to give up. So we have an idea. We Iowans can give up the first-in-the-nation status in exchange for... wait for it... moving the nation's capital to Des Moines.
Consider the benefits: Iowa would no longer endure attention from scornful coast-dwellers every four years. Perhaps we could even become the Landlocked Elites, scornful of those suckers dwelling by the rising seas. We could move to a ranked-choice primary system, avoid disenfranchising anyone, and let other states bicker over who should be anointed Most Reflective Of The U.S. As A Whole and therefore go first.
Washington, D.C., could finally become a state, change its license plates, and stop putting up with people constantly marching all over. (No problem for Des Moines; it should be well-prepared for all sorts of marching after this cycle's parade of presidential candidates.) And no more jokes about Flyover Country when we are the physical heart and soul of the country.
It's really not healthy or sensible for the capital of our country — once so centrally located among 13 states — to be as remote as Washington, D.C., can be. So just like the Iowa capital moved westward as the state's population grew westward, we should finally move the capital of the United States to the heart of the country. Based on the scope of the media uproar over Iowa's first-in-the-nation caucus over the past month, we're confident that everyone from the New York Times to the L.A. Times will be on board, and we look forward to having the President ensconced in the Golden-Domed House by 2024.
Writers' Group members Kelcey Patrick-Ferree and Shannon Patrick live in Iowa City. And biannual time changes must be abolished.
Your Turn
Kelcey Patrick-Ferree and Shannon Patrick
Guest columnists

MSU's Wharton staff to be restructured

Autor: Johnson, Mark. 

Información de publicación: Detroit Free Press ; Detroit, Mich. [Detroit, Mich]. 08 Feb 2020: A.5.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/msus-wharton-staff-be-restructured/docview/2352279047/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=MSU%27s+Wharton+staff+to+be+restructured%3A+Controversy+arose+from+the+way+black+figures+displayed&amp;author=Johnson%2C+Mark&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.5&amp;date=2020-02-08&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Detroit+Free+Press&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Amidwestnews1_

Texto completo: EAST LANSING — Michigan State University President Samuel Stanley said staff at the Wharton Center is being restructured after a gift shop display of dolls depicting black historical figures hanging from a rack resembling a tree led to widespread outrage.
In a letter he sent to the MSU community on Thursday and posted on the president's website, Stanley apologized for the display. He promised the university is taking the situation seriously and taking steps to prevent such incidents from occurring in the future.
"This was a disturbing reminder of our country's history of terror and unrelenting brutality that targeted individuals based on their race," Stanley wrote. "Members of our community were hurt. Though this display was created to honor prominent African Americans during Black History Month, we cannot ignore the historical context that made it exceedingly painful and traumatic to our community members.
"This display was unacceptable and should never have been put up. I'm sorry that this happened. It has been taken down. We can, and must, do better as Spartans. We need to do the necessary work that better informs our thinking and deepens our understanding of how our actions affect others."
"The center is undergoing a full restructuring of staff, including management," Stanley wrote in the letter. More details were not in the letter, but Dan Olsen, an MSU spokesman, said the reorganization will be confined to gift shop staff.
Stanley wrote that diversity within the center's workforce would be a priority.
All staff and volunteers also will go through mandatory racial-bias education and development starting Wednesday in coordination with the MSU Office for Inclusion and Intercultural Initiatives.
Olsen said the Wharton Center will reevaluate the roles and responsibilities for gift shop workers and volunteers. A final determination will be made once those employees and volunteers complete the racial-bias education and development.
Additional plans are in the works to make a diversity, equity, and inclusion committee consisting of faculty, staff, students, volunteers and other community members to "bring a diverse range of identities and perspectives to the Wharton Center," according to Stanley.
"There is no denying this happened on our campus, at a location that was meant to recognize the contributions of MSU's past president, Clifton R. Wharton Jr., a great American and MSU leader and his wife, Dolores Wharton, who both came to campus with a deep appreciation for the arts," Stanley wrote in the letter. "We have work to do."
Wharton, 93, served as MSU's president from 1970 to 1978. His tenure at MSU marked the first time a black president was selected by a major university where the majority of students were white, the New York Times reported. Wharton left MSU to serve as chancellor of the State University of New York and later held business and diplomatic roles, including Under Secretary of State in the Clinton Administration.
While at MSU, Wharton and his wife, Dolores, promoted the plan to build a new performance venue to replace the aging MSU Auditorium. They also headed the successful fundraising campaign. When the new performing arts center opened in 1982, it was named in their honor.
The display in the gift shop was discovered last week. It featured a rack resembling a tree to hang felt ornaments resembling Michelle Obama, Barack Obama, Prince and other African-American leaders.
Krystal Rose Davis-Dunn, a 31-year-old black graduate student at MSU, came across the displays after a jazz concert she had attended with a friend who wanted to check out the gift shop after the show. The dolls hanging from the tree was one of the first things she noticed when they walked in.
They kept walking around and she spotted four or five similar trees and a larger tree with "a lot more" black leaders.
"The Wharton Center recognizes the need for greater diversity among its staff and volunteers and for creating an environment that reflects our best efforts. However, they are not alone in that need," Stanley wrote. "Our entire campus must view this as an opportunity to learn and reflect on what we can and should do to create a safe and inclusive culture, and we must hold ourselves accountable for achieving these goals."

Mets suitor Cohen: 'I gave it my best shot'

Autor: Toscano, Justin. 

Información de publicación: Courier - News ; Bridgewater, N.J. [Bridgewater, N.J]. 08 Feb 2020: B.3.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/mets-suitor-cohen-i-gave-my-best-shot/docview/2352278977/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Mets+suitor+Cohen%3A+%27I+gave+it+my+best+shot%27&amp;author=Toscano%2C+Justin&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=B.3&amp;date=2020-02-08&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Courier+-+News&amp;issn=0895-8785&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: Were the Steven Cohen-Sterling Partners talks actually in danger?
Since Tuesday, everyone has pondered it. An answer arrived two days later.
The deal to purchase the New York Mets is dead, though the Wilpons are still looking to sell.
"The transaction between Sterling and Steve Cohen was a highly complicated one," Sterling Partners, which is owned by Fred Wilpon, said in a statement on Thursday night. "Despite the efforts of the parties over the past several months, it became apparent that the transaction as contemplated would have been too difficult to execute.
"Sterling intends now to pursue a new transaction and has engaged Allen & Company to manage that process."
Via a statement to the New York Times, Cohen said: "I'm very disappointed we couldn't work out a deal, but as an 8 percent holder (in the Mets), I'm looking forward to a higher bid for the team."
In December, the Sterling Partners announced it was negotiating to sell a majority share of the Mets to Cohen, a hedge-fund billionaire. Under the agreement, Fred and Jeff Wilpon would retain their titles for five years.
Earlier on Thursday, MLB commissioner Rob Manfred dealt a bit of a reality blow to those hoping the Wilpons would be able to sell the Mets to Cohen. Manfred, while speaking at the owners meetings in Florida, said it was this transaction would not occur.
"I want to thank the fans for their support and the respect they showed me," Cohen said, "and I want to thank Commissioner Manfred and MLB for their support through the process.
"I gave it my best shot."
On Tuesday, a Barstool Sports podcast reported that negotiations were not going well. Hours later, the Mets released this statement: "The parties are subject to confidentiality obligations, including a mutual non-disclosure agreement, and therefore cannot comment."
Sometimes, silence or a no comment is seen is a negative. We didn't know in this case, mostly because non-disclosure agreements are common in business. The speculation began.
Were the Wilpons at fault again? What happened to the deal? Was this news leak a negotiation ploy used to gain leverage?
Per the New York Post on Wednesday, "the Wilpons recently made it clear to Cohen that while he would be paying hundreds of millions of dollars every year, they would in fact retain control over all decision-making regarding the franchise until the end of five years."
This Cohen snag is the latest in a line of weird situations involving the Wilpons.
In 2011, hedge-fund manager David Einhorn accused the Wilpons of changing the terms to his deal to buy a minority stake in the Mets.
Nine years before, the Wilpons became owners when Fred bought out Nelson Doubleday. But Doubleday levied accusations of misconduct over what the team was valued.
Manfred on Thursday said that any accusation that the Wilpons acted in bad faith was "completely and utterly unfair."
As the statement at the top of this story outlines, the Wilpons still intend to search for a new transaction. The timeline is unknown.
The Mets for years have been branded as the big-market team that rarely spends like it. Fans hoped Cohen — who would've been the richest owner in baseball — could immediately alter that perception.
It will have to be someone else, unless the two sides reconvene in the future.
This saga caps a wild offseason for the Mets, who ...
Fired a manager, hired a manager, parted with the first manager, hired a new manager. Oh, and that doesn't count the personnel moves and restructuring Yoenis Céspedes' contract.
Pitchers and catchers report to Port St. Lucie, Florida, for spring training next week. Finally, baseball will be the center of conversation — or at least you'd hope. But the Mets remained active, for better or worse, over the last four months.
On Tuesday, news broke that talks were not going well. But the fact that was leaked, some speculated, was a negotiation ploy.
It was not. There will be no deal between the Mets and Cohen.

Tips for married couples on Valentine's Day

Información de publicación: News Herald ; Port Clinton, Ohio [Port Clinton, Ohio]. 08 Feb 2020: A.2.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/tips-married-couples-on-valentines-day/docview/2352278906/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Tips+for+married+couples+on+Valentine%27s+Day&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.2&amp;date=2020-02-08&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=News+Herald&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Amidwestnews1_

Texto completo: Valentine's Day is coming! Prepare yourself for an onslaught of Instagram posts featuring bright flowers, sparkling jewelry, and oversized teddy bears. Your feed is about to get #blessed. If you get to know me for more than 10 seconds, you know that's not what I'm about. Heck, my husband isn't even on social media. And I'm okay with that.
One study wanted to find out if couples who post excessively about each other are actually happier in their relationships. Spoiler alert: They're not. The study found "over-the-top displays are being used to compensate for weaker relationships."
This doesn't mean you don't love your husband if you talk about how wonderful he is on social media. Hopefully, you and your spouse affirm each other daily and in person.
But when I think about the healthiest couples I know, they're not the ones posting about each other 24/7. They're also not worried about what other people think, so they're not buying more stuff to impress people (just so they can post about it). They're secure in their lives, but not because of an expensive lifestyle that they can flaunt. Instead, the couples I look up to have one thing in common — they're all intentional in their marriages.
A strong marriage doesn't happen by chance. If you want to be intentional and make your spouse feel really secure, work together on these three areas:
1. Set goals together A 2017 study by Ramsey Solutions revealed that 94 percent of couples who describe their marriages as "great" also say they discuss money goals together. Getting on the same page financially with your spouse is one of the best things you can do for your marriage. If you need some help reconnecting and realigning the goals of your relationship, check out this episode of The Rachel Cruze Show (rachelcruze.com/show/money-mistakes-that-can-ruin-your-relationships). You'll learn about money mistakes that can ruin your relationship, and practical ways to communicate and work better together.
2. Be willing to have tough conversations My friend, Dr. Les Parrott, says conflict is the price we pay for a deeper level of intimacy. You can disagree, and still make space to hear each other. Hashing it out, putting in the work, and coming from a place of understanding will only make you stronger. And by the way, I'm a huge fan of counseling for every marriage, not just the ones in crisis mode.
3. Don't compare your marriage to someone else's Comparison will steal your joy and frustrate your spouse. Too many people let Instagram-level expectations form their values and family priorities. I've been there, too, and I know it's an empty and endless battle trying to keep up. Spend that time and energy focusing on all the things you truly love about your spouse, and the life you've already built together.
Flowers will die, and jewelry will tarnish. But a relationship built on these three principles will make your marriage a blessing, not just #blessed.
As a No. 1 New York Times best-selling author, host of The Rachel Cruze Show, and The Rachel Cruze Show podcast, Rachel helps people learn the proper ways to handle money and stay out of debt. You can follow Cruze at rachelcruze.com.
Rachel Cruze
Columnist
Most Valentine's Day gifts don't last, but couples who are intentional about their marriages can have healthy relationships that last a lifetime.
Plus Plus / Haba

Puerto Rico aid bill goes to Senate House approval comes amid White House veto threat

Autor: Lemongello, Steven. 

Información de publicación: Orlando Sentinel ; Orlando, Fla. [Orlando, Fla]. 08 Feb 2020: B.1.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/puerto-rico-aid-bill-goes-senate-house-approval/docview/2352277912/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Puerto+Rico+aid+bill+goes+to+Senate+House+approval+comes+amid+White+House+veto+threat&amp;author=Lemongello%2C+Steven&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=B.1&amp;date=2020-02-08&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Orlando+Sentinel&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asoutheastnews_

Texto completo: The House of Representatives approved $4.67 billion in additional aid relief to Puerto Rico on Friday, with just three GOP congressmen from Florida joining 14 other Republicans in voting for the bill.
But with a threat to veto the bill coming from the White House, it's unclear if the Senate will even hold a vote. And Florida's GOP senators were noncommittal.
Republican U.S. Reps. Michael Waltz, R-St. Augustine, Mario Diaz-Balart, R-Miami, and Bill Posey, R-Rockledge, in joining the Democratic majority in voting in favor.
More than $3 billion would be allocated for disaster-relief grants, as well as more than $200 million for the food-stamp program and about $18 million to bolster the island's electrical grid, according to the New York Times.
The White House Office of Management and Budget issued a statement Wednesday opposing the bill, saying the island is already "projected to receive $90 billion in disaster funds."
That includes the $44 billion currently allocated to Puerto Rico, $22 billion the government has promised to spend.
While President Donald Trump has often touted a $90 billion or $91 billion number, PolitiFact reported he probably included additional estimated FEMA costs of $50 billion, which is a speculative "high-end estimate of what would need to be committed" over the course of many years. None of that money has yet been allocated.
The OMB said the House was "rushing this bill through its process - and seeking to push taxpayer dollars out the door - even before the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) has completed its review of the damage caused by earthquakes that have recently affected the island."
It recommended a Trump veto of the bill, adding, "neither Puerto Ricans nor the American taxpayers benefit when emergency aid is misallocated, lost, or stolen through waste, fraud, and abuse," and citing Puerto Rico's "long history of inadequate financial controls over regular government operations."
"Multiple high-profile cases of corruption have marred distribution of aid already appropriated and have led to ongoing political instability on the island," the OMB stated.
Terrie Rizzo, the Florida Democratic chair, said in a statement Thursday, "Here we go again."
"Trump has consistently failed Puerto Ricans since he took office - he has neglected to distribute the billions of dollars in aid that Congress approved following Hurricane Maria's devastation; he ignored the island during his recent State of the Union Address; and now, he is threatening to veto necessary aid after major earthquakes further damaged the island," Rizzo said.
U.S. Rep. Darren Soto, D-Kissimmee, also wrote in a tweet, "When our brothers & sisters in Puerto Rico are in need, WE ACT. I urge my colleagues in the Senate to move quickly in delivering on our promise to help our fellow Americans recover & rebuild."
U.S. Rep. Stephanie Murphy, D-Winter Park, said in a statement, "Every dollar is critical-and every dollar must be accounted for and reach the Puerto Rico residents who need it most."
In the Republican Senate, there were mixed messages as to whether a companion bill would pass or even come up for a vote following the White House veto threat.
Senate Appropriations Chairman Richard Shelby, R-Ala., told Bloomberg News he believes the island needs more help, saying, "We'll do whatever it takes. This is serious, serious, serious business."
A spokesperson for Republican U.S. Sen. Rick Scott said he was "reviewing" the bill but wouldn't commit to it.
"The Senator is in constant communication with the Island's leadership, FEMA, and has spoken to the President about the importance of quickly getting aid to Puerto Rico," his office stated. "Senator Scott also met with Governor Vazquez and Congresswoman Jenniffer González-Colón this week to discuss the resources Puerto Rico needs to recover from the earthquakes, and he will always work to support our brothers and sisters on the Island."
Republican U.S. Sen. Marco Rubio's office was also noncommittal on whether Rubio would support the bill.

slemongello@orlandosentinel.com

Supporters, protesters gather at Bloomberg's Norfolk campaign stop Candidate makes 5th visit to state since November

Autor: Saleen, Martin. 

Información de publicación: Daily Press ; Newport News, Va. [Newport News, Va]. 08 Feb 2020: A.7.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/supporters-protesters-gather-at-bloombergs/docview/2352277800/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Supporters%2C+protesters+gather+at+Bloomberg%27s+Norfolk+campaign+stop+Candidate+makes+5th+visit+to+state+since+November&amp;author=Saleen%2C+Martin&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.7&amp;date=2020-02-08&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Daily+Press&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asoutheastnews_

Texto completo: Some signs read "Trump 2020." Another said "We don't need your dirty $$." And another said "Killing tiny humans is not health care."
A crowd of protesters joined dozens of supporters at presidential candidate Mike Bloomberg's campaign event Friday in Norfolk. It's his fifth visit to Virginia since launching his campaign in November, his team said.
One man, Rick Bryson, went to protest with his 13-year-old son.
"I served 25 years in the Air Force," Bryson said. "I thought I had solidified my rights in this country. Now, you have somebody like (Mike Bloomberg) trying to come in and take my Second Amendment rights."
He said legislators want to take away guns so that they can rule over citizens, like a dictatorship. He didn't go register for the event or head inside.
"I will not give them money to talk to somebody that doesn't want to hear what you have to say," he said.
Lisa Ross didn't register, either, but stood outside the gate in front of the Half Moone Cruise & Celebration Center to see what was going on. The Virginia Beach resident wanted to learn more about Bloomberg, she said.
"I've followed his commercials," she said. "I've followed a little bit about him."
She said she has some concerns about his track record as mayor of New York City, including his stance on stop-and-frisk policies, which targeted blacks and Latinos, The New York Times reported. Bloomberg apologized in November for supporting the strategy.
Ross, who is undecided on for whom she will vote, hoped to learn more about what Bloomberg hopes to bring to the table, and see how authentic he is. She also said he is interesting because of his approach to his candidacy.
"It's so tactical and money is no object," she later said in an email. "I'll be doing some additional research on his ideas."
Cheri Britt traveled from Williamsburg to protest in support of gun rights and against abortion rights.
Holding a sign that read "Killing tiny humans is not health care," she said Bloomberg supports a woman's right to choose without fully understanding it.
"I'm all for choice myself," she said. "Where you send your kids to school, who you marry, where you go to school. All those things. But ending the life of another human being is not another choice that we should have."
While waiting in line to get into the event, Keith Ehrhard and his wife, Merri, said they were there to make a more informed decision about the 2020 election.
"I think everybody in the country should be doing the same thing," he said.
"We've just got to beat Trump," his wife chimed in with a laugh.

A CHANCE AT FREEDOM

Autor: HANNAN ADELYNORTHJERSEYCOM. 

Información de publicación: Courier - News ; Bridgewater, N.J. [Bridgewater, N.J]. 08 Feb 2020: A.5.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/chance-at-freedom/docview/2352277758/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=A+CHANCE+AT+FREEDOM%3A+AT+SETON+HALL%2C+A+QUEST+TO+GET+THE+INNOCENT+OUT+OF+JAIL&amp;author=HANNAN+ADELYNORTHJERSEYCOM&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.5&amp;date=2020-02-08&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Courier+-+News&amp;issn=0895-8785&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: For nearly a decade, Lesley and D. Michael Risinger pored over transcripts, interviewed witnesses, consulted firearms experts and argued in courtrooms, with help of a team of Seton Hall law students.
Their goal: Free two men they believed were wrongly convicted for a double murder in Camden a quarter-century ago.
That chance at freedom came Dec. 26, when a New Jersey appeals court overturned the convictions and ordered a new trial for Kevin Baker and Shawn Washington, who were found guilty of the killings and locked away in state prison in 1996.
For the husband-and-wife legal team who run the Last Resort Exoneration Project at Seton Hall Law School in Newark, it was a hard-fought first victory after years of work to make the justice system face up to its own flaws.
"There's nothing worse than being locked up for something you didn't do, especially if it's a long sentence," said Lesley Risinger, who co-founded the program in 2011 and serves as director. "When someone is locked up, possibly for life, for a crime they had nothing to do with, it's a thing you get inside you and that you feel is intolerable."
The Exoneration Project is driven by a key premise — that the criminal justice system makes mistakes and may send people to prison for crimes they did not commit. An estimated 1% to 5% of those in prison have been wrongfully convicted, according to a report last year ordered by New Jersey Attorney General Gurbir Grewal.
Assuming a 1% rate of wrongful conviction in New Jersey, nearly 200 of those currently in a state prison population of about 19,500 people are innocent. Yet there have been only 37 overturned convictions in the state since 1989, the report said.
'Total failure of the defense' Lesley Risinger first got involved in cases of the wrongfully accused nearly 30 years ago, when she helped her mother, an attorney, appeal the conviction of Luis Kevin Rojas of Weehawken. Rojas, 18 at the time of the alleged crime, had been found guilty of a fatal shooting in 1990, but the case was marred by mistaken identity and missing eyewitness testimony, his attorneys successfully argued. He was freed after a retrial in 1998. Risinger later represented Fernando Bermudez, who was convicted in a 1991 Manhattan murder, but the case was based on perjured testimony, Risinger argued. In 2009, a judge freed Bermudez after 18 years in prison.
In 2011, the Risingers launched the Last Resort Exoneration Project and got many letters from prisoners claiming innocence and looking for help. With help from law students, they vet cases for evidence that could prove a conviction was improper.
The application from Kevin Baker, one of the two convicts in the Camden case, was compelling.
"It cried out for attention simply based on the weakness of the evidence and the total failure of the defense to present a defense," said Lesley Risinger, 62, a former adjunct professor who graduated from the law school in 2003.
The case rested on testimony from a single witness who was high on crack at the time of the shooting and whose story was so shaky that defense lawyers thought it wouldn't be believed, Risinger said. The state called six witnesses during the two-day trial, while the defense called none, court records show.
The proceedings ended in a guilty verdict and life sentences with no chance of parole for 60 years. John Wynne, an assistant Camden County prosecutor on the case, told The New York Times in 1996 that even he was surprised by the verdict.
"We had to do the investigation that should have been done then," said D. Michael Risinger, 72, the associate director of the Exoneration Project.
Last month, a state appeals court finally agreed, ordering a new trial. The court ruled that additional evidence not presented at the time "probably would have changed the jury's verdict." Jurors never heard a recording of Baker's 911 call or a forensics analysis showing that the shooting could not have happened as the witness described, the court found.
Baker and Washington, who is represented by Lawrence Lustberg, an attorney with Gibbons P.C. in Newark, remain in state prison in Trenton waiting to find out whether the Camden County prosecutor will seek a new trial.
The Risingers hope a conviction review unit created by the New Jersey Attorney General's Office last year will end the case and the Prosecutor's Office will determine that pursuing it "would be fruitless and unjust."
In a statement, Grewal said his office and Camden prosecutors are "committed to pursuing the just result in each and every case.
"We are actively reviewing this case, including the trial evidence and the extensive appellate and post-conviction proceedings that have taken place over the past 25 years," Grewal said.
A passion for the work The Last Resort Exoneration Project is similar to "innocence projects" that rely on DNA to prove that individuals did not commit crimes of which they were accused.
But the Risingers have taken an even more difficult route, choosing cases that lack DNA evidence but where other facts show the defendants did not receive a fair trial. They said they closely review applications to see where there's a strong legal case to prove innocence.
The Baker case is the Exoneration Project's first overturned conviction and required extensive litigation, expert analysis and hundreds of legal exhibits. The Risingers said they have also given close consideration to at least a dozen more cases.
About half a dozen law school students volunteer with the program each year. Over nine years, about a dozen worked on the Camden case, studying case files, reviewing trial documents and giving feedback on oral arguments.
They include Renee Mariotti, a part-time law student from New York City who chose Seton Hall Law in part for the chance to work at the Exoneration Project. Her interest came after listening to podcasts about wrongful convictions, in particular the Baltimore murder case of Adnan Syed made famous in the podcast "Serial."
"These are men who have been imprisoned for, coming up on 25 years, crimes they did not commit," Mariotti said of Baker and Washington. "It's nice to see the law working in what feels like the right way in this case. That's not always the outcome."
Amy Cuzzolino, a Bloomfield native who graduated in 2016, helped review applications to find viable legal cases. Her work gave her more insight into how the justice system works — and fails, she said.
"I didn't come away with a sense that the system is bad because of bad actors in it. It's more a question of inefficiency and limited resources. There are a lot of people who want to do the right thing but don't know how," said Cuzzolino, who is studying for an advanced degree in international law.
The Risingers, who live in Kearny, don't take a salary for their work. Private donations to the program pay for expenses like buying transcripts and consulting experts.
Michael Risinger, who worked on civil rights cases involving wrongful police shootings in the '70s and '80s, said he has devoted his career to making sure the legal system is accurate, especially in criminal cases. The former Seton Hall law professor served on the New Jersey Supreme Court's Committee on Evidence for 25 years.
He and his wife, who married in 2004 and have six children from previous marriages, see their work with the Exoneration Project as a calling, he said.
"We have sufficient money. We live very frugally, and we don't have ambitions to take grand tours or anything," he said. "We'd rather do this."

____________________________________________________________

Kentuckian caught in 'ghost town' amid coronavirus scare

Autor: Kenning, Chris. 

Información de publicación: Courier - Journal ; Louisville, Ky. [Louisville, Ky]. 08 Feb 2020: A.8.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/kentuckian-caught-ghost-town-amid-coronavirus/docview/2352277207/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Kentuckian+caught+in+%27ghost+town%27+amid+coronavirus+scare&amp;author=Kenning%2C+Chris&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.8&amp;date=2020-02-08&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Courier+-+Journal&amp;issn=1930-2177&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Amidwestnews1_

Texto completo: Kyle Johnson can't enter his high-rise apartment tower outside Shanghai without being greeted by men in white biosafety suits who take his temperature each time to check for signs of the coronavirus.
Although he's hundreds of miles from Wuhan, China, where the outbreak of the deadly flu-like illness began, the international school where the Kentucky native teaches history is closed, along with many local shops and restaurants. Taxi drivers who ferry him for groceries wear face masks. The area has a 9 p.m. curfew.
"It feels a little like a ghost town," said Johnson, who grew up in Woodford County and lived for a time in Louisville before taking a teaching job in China about six months ago.
Johnson, 30, is among a wide range of Kentucky-connected teachers, students, business people and others affected by the travel restrictions and global response to the deadly coronavirus outbreak, which had infected more than 31,400 people.
The death toll was at nearly 640 Friday, with almost all of those in China.
Just 12 cases have been confirmed in the U.S., according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
The U.S. and other nations have moved to temporarily block the entry of noncitizens from China, and hundreds of Americans who were evacuated from China are being quarantined for two weeks.
In China, officials have restricted people's movement and closed some public transit in hopes of containing the virus.
All that has left Johnson holed up in his apartment in China, where authorities have extended the Lunar New Year holiday break, which was due to end this week, well into February to reduce the virus's spread. That decision has left Johnson's school closed for the rest of the month.
He has decided to stay put and is unlikely to return home anytime soon. Multiple airlines have halted or curtailed China flights.
"I saw that U.S. citizens coming to America from China had to spend two weeks in quarantine anyway, so I'd be doing the same thing, hanging out and watching movies," he said.
One woman and her 8-year-old daughter with Kentucky ties living in Wuhan were among those evacuated by a U.S. chartered flight last week, WLEX-TV reported. The woman filmed her trip to the airport, which showed eerily empty streets.
In Kentucky, the virus has upended travel plans for employees of businesses such as Papa John's International and led universities to cancel travel to China study programs. They have urged students to adhere to U.S. State Department warnings against traveling to China.
The University of Kentucky, which had one staffer stuck in the quarantine zone in China while visiting for a funeral, hosts more than 500 Chinese students on campus. Many are worried about family, rescheduling trips and unsure when they can return, officials said.
"They're all in contact with families" on social media, said Huajing Maske, executive director of UK's Confucius Institute and director of the Office of China Initiatives.
Zhizhi Wang, 25, a graduate finance student, said his family is hunkered down in Yueyang, about a 30-minute train ride from Wuhan. From Lexington, he's been in touch daily on WeChat.
"When the Wuhan government issued a city lockdown, 10,000 people fled the city and camped in my hometown. That's when we freaked out," he said. "I told my family, just don't go out. You never know who you're going to bump into."
Cases have grown in the last week. "It's pretty scary," he said.
Some residents are afraid to visit those in hospitals and New Year's celebrations are taking place on social media video, not in person.
The New York Times reported Thursday that Wuhan officials had been ordered to round up all residents who have been infected with the coronavirus and place them in isolation, quarantine or designated hospitals.
In Kentucky, Wang has seen reported instances on Chinese American community social media chats of schoolkids being subject to phrases such as "Chinese virus, stay away!" he said, with many feeling that referring to it a "Chinese virus" was discriminatory.
Chang Zheng Wang, of Lexington, past president of the Kentucky Chinese American Association, said his relatives "are still safe, they're just stuck in the house every day. All the trains, buses, public transport is stopped, people can't go anywhere. One of my nieces works in a hospital, and they're seeing a lot of (coronavirus) patients."
Central China's Hubei province has added thousands of beds by building two new hospitals and creating quarantine centers.
The province has been in virtual lockdown, and international news has shown quiet, empty streets and residents staying distracted with television and food delivery.
CNN reported that social media videos show people coming up with all kinds of activities to kill time, including playing pingpong on dinner tables.
Far to the east, Johnson, who teaches at Kang Chiao International School, where students prepare to study at colleges in the U.S., has been largely stuck inside the apartment building he shares with other foreign teachers. Many had left for the break and have delayed their return.
Government workers came to his door to ask about his travel history, he said. And while public transportation has been shut down in some areas, buses still run where he lives.
Across China and beyond, fears of infection have spread with the virus. In Hong Kong, hit hard in 2002 by SARS, a highly contagious respiratory illness, thousands of hospital workers went on strike earlier to demand complete closure of the border. Other countries are continuing evacuations and restricting the entry of Chinese or people who have recently traveled in the country.
The new virus's mortality rate is about 2%, lower than SARS, which has a mortality rate of about 10%.
Sylvie Birand, director of global infections hazard preparedness at the World Health Organization, has told USA TODAY it was "very early" in the outbreak. She declined to describe the situation as a pandemic, saying the outbreak remained mostly contained in China.
Johnson said one friend refers to it as a "panic-demic."
He said people should remember that news reports often focus on the hardest-hit areas and response efforts, which have fueled concern from some friends and family in Kentucky. He said he doesn't believe he'll come in contact with the virus.
"People are calling. ... 'Oh my God, three hundred people died," he said. While reading about it from afar may make it seem like "something out of a zombie movie," he said, at least in his area, "it's not as scary being here as it looks."
Reporter Chris Kenning can be reached at ckenning@gannett.com or 502-396-3361 or on Twitter @chris_kenning.
CREDIT: Chris Kenning

Suitor to buy Mets: 'I gave it my best shot'

Autor: Toscano, Justin. 

Información de publicación: Rochester Democrat and Chronicle ; Rochester, N.Y. [Rochester, N.Y]. 08 Feb 2020: D.2.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/suitor-buy-mets-i-gave-my-best-shot/docview/2352277172/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Suitor+to+buy+Mets%3A+%27I+gave+it+my+best+shot%27%3A+Cohen+spent+months+trying+to+make+deal&amp;author=Toscano%2C+Justin&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.2&amp;date=2020-02-08&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Rochester+Democrat+and+Chronicle&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: Were the Steven Cohen-Sterling Partners talks actually in danger?
Since Tuesday, everyone has pondered it. An answer arrived two days later.
The deal to purchase the New York Mets is dead, though the Wilpons are still looking to sell.
"The transaction between Sterling and Steve Cohen was a highly complicated one," Sterling Partners, which is owned by Fred Wilpon, said in a statement on Thursday night. "Despite the efforts of the parties over the past several months, it became apparent that the transaction as contemplated would have been too difficult to execute.
"Sterling intends now to pursue a new transaction and has engaged Allen & Company to manage that process."
Via a statement to the New York Times, Cohen said: "I'm very disappointed we couldn't work out a deal, but as an 8 percent holder (in the Mets), I'm looking forward to a higher bid for the team."
In December, the Sterling Partners announced it was negotiating to sell a majority share of the Mets to Cohen, a hedge-fund billionaire. Under the agreement, Fred and Jeff Wilpon would retain their titles for five years.
Earlier on Thursday, MLB commissioner Rob Manfred dealt a bit of a reality blow to those hoping the Wilpons would be able to sell the Mets to Cohen. Manfred, while speaking at the owners meetings in Florida, said it was this transaction would not occur.
"I want to thank the fans for their support and the respect they showed me," Cohen said, "and I want to thank Commissioner Manfred and MLB for their support through the process.
"I gave it my best shot."
On Tuesday, a Barstool Sports podcast reported that negotiations were not going well. Hours later, the Mets released this statement: "The parties are subject to confidentiality obligations, including a mutual non-disclosure agreement, and therefore cannot comment."
Sometimes, silence or a no comment is seen is a negative. We didn't know in this case, mostly because non-disclosure agreements are common in business. The speculation began.
Were the Wilpons at fault again? What happened to the deal? Was this news leak a negotiation ploy used to gain leverage?
Per the New York Post on Wednesday, "the Wilpons recently made it clear to Cohen that while he would be paying hundreds of millions of dollars every year, they would in fact retain control over all decision-making regarding the franchise until the end of five years."
This Cohen snag is the latest in a line of weird situations involving the Wilpons.
In 2011, hedge-fund manager David Einhorn accused the Wilpons of changing the terms to his deal to buy a minority stake in the Mets.
Nine years before, the Wilpons became owners when Fred bought out Nelson Doubleday. But Doubleday levied accusations of misconduct over what the team was valued.
Manfred on Thursday said that any accusation that the Wilpons acted in bad faith was "completely and utterly unfair."
As the statement at the top of this story outlines, the Wilpons still intend to search for a new transaction. The timeline is unknown.
The Mets for years have been branded as the big-market team that rarely spends like it. Fans hoped Cohen — who would've been the richest owner in baseball — could immediately alter that perception.
It will have to be someone else, unless the two sides reconvene in the future.
This saga caps a wild offseason for the Mets, who ...
Fired a manager, hired a manager, parted with the first manager, hired a new manager. Oh, and that doesn't count the personnel moves and restructuring Yoenis Céspedes' contract.
Pitchers and catchers report to Port St. Lucie, Florida, for spring training next week. Finally, baseball will be the center of conversation — or at least you'd hope. But the Mets remained active, for better or worse, over the last four months.
On Tuesday, news broke that talks were not going well. But the fact that was leaked, some speculated, was a negotiation ploy.
It was not. There will be no deal between the Mets and Cohen.
Email: toscanoj@northjersey.com
CREDIT: Justin Toscano

____________________________________________________________

1970 hit 'Love Story' is back in theaters. Go see it

Autor: Beckerman, Jim. 

Información de publicación: Daily Record ; Morristown, N.J. [Morristown, N.J]. 08 Feb 2020: D.2.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/1970-hit-love-story-is-back-theaters-go-see/docview/2352277114/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=1970+hit+%27Love+Story%27+is+back+in+theaters.+Go+see+it&amp;author=Beckerman%2C+Jim&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.2&amp;date=2020-02-08&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Daily+Record&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: Loving "Love Story" means never having to say you're sorry you love "Love Story."
No apologies. No denials. No remarks like, "I know it's corny, but..."
Go on, weep. Let it out.
Bawl into your popcorn as lovely Ali McGraw, the spirited Radcliffe music major, says her deathbed farewell to Ryan O'Neal, the handsome Harvard preppie. "Love means never having to say you're sorry," she tells him — in the movie, on the poster, and in that mystic land where pop culture clichés live forever.
What can you say about an iconic movie that is coming back to theaters for Valentine's Day week?
That it grossed $106 million? That it was a surprise mega-hit in 1970? That it divided the nation between those who wept and those who snickered?
That you can see it at 1 p.m. Feb. 9 and 7 p.m. Feb. 12 at AMC Theaters across the country?
In a way, "Love Story" was an early broadside in the culture wars. It pit the critical elites, who mocked it in print and on TV, against Mr. and Mrs. Average American, who thought it was just swell. "You ain't human if you don't cry at that movie," said a character, defensively, in a TV sitcom of the era.
"I think both of those arguments — those who were moved to tears, and those who thought it was sappy and sentimental — have a point," said TCM host Ben Mankiewicz, who will be introducing the screenings, sponsored by Fathom Events, Turner Classic Movies and Paramount Pictures.
Among the things critics cackled over in 1970: the malady (never named) that doomed Jenny Cavalieri dies from. What kind of illness makes you even prettier on your deathbed? "Old Movie Disease" was the diagnosis of Mad Magazine.
"I suspect cancer makes people uncomfortable," Mankiewicz said. "That certainly would not be the case if they remade it today."
As for the heroine who becomes more beautiful as she dies — well, in operas, the heroine sings as she dies. "I think if the doctors accept it, and Ryan O'Neal accepts it, we accept it," Mankiewicz said. "We just buy what the characters in the movie accept. That's one of the beautiful things about movies."
As "Love Story" turned into the No. 1 grosser of 1970, and the book became the top-selling work of fiction the same year — the first time a novelization made it to the New York Times bestseller lists — it propelled writer Erich Segal, a Harvard classics professor and sometime movie writer ("Yellow Submarine") to fame as the culture warrior of the squares.
A key moment of the era was a January 1971 Dick Cavett Show, when Segal shared the stage with snide highbrow critic John Simon and rocker Little Richard.
"I have read and reread ["Love Story"] many times," Segal told Cavett modestly. "I am always moved."
Simon called Segal a "knave." Segal called Simon an "effete litterateur."
It was a momentous clash — so much so that later, commentators offered different versions, "Rashomon"-style.
To sci-fi writer Harlan Ellison (he had a TV column at the time), it was nothing less than a pivotal moment in Western civilization. Simon, the heroic critic, was the only thing standing between us and the Visigoths.
"Debasing emotions like love and recognition of one's own mortality," Ellison said, is "the cheap trick of panhandlers, flack merchants, con men."
"I am not bought that cheaply," said Ellison, grandly. "And neither are my tears."
Meanwhile, rock critic Greil Marcus saw both Simon and Segal as frauds. "Little Richard was the only artist on the stage that night," he wrote in his book "Mystery Train."
In the end, civilization survived. So did "Love Story." The famous theme music by Francis Lai became a favorite piece of elevator music, in versions by Ferrante & Teicher, Mantovani, and Andy Williams. There was a sequel, "Oliver's Story."
"This is a story of capitalism, as much as it is a love story," Mankiewicz said. "The people who made it were looking to make money."
Harvard freshmen, it is said, are still shown "Love Story" as part of orientation week. They cackle, hoot, and send it up, a la "Rocky Horror Picture Show."
They have every right. Harvard is not only the setting of the film but also the inspiration for the characters. Oliver is said to be a mashup of Harvard graduates Al Gore and Tommy Lee Jones; Jones made his film debut in the movie.
"Segal went to Harvard and he knew those guys," Mankiewicz said. "It makes sense that he would craft the character of Oliver out of the Harvard students that he knew."
For the rest of us, "Love Story" is a movie that can still move, Mankiewicz said. In a battle between the head and heart, most moviegoers will go for the tear ducts.
"If what you really want is to immerse yourself in a cinematic experience, I think being moved is going to win," he said.
Email: beckerman@northjersey.com Twitter: @jimbeckerman1
Ryan O'Neal and Ali MacGraw in "Love Story."
Paramount Pictures
CREDIT: Jim Beckerman

Materia: Books

Lugar: New York

Personas: MacGraw, Ali Jones, Tommy Lee Gore, Albert Jr Segal, Erich

Empresa/organización: Nombre: New York Times Co; NAICS: 511110, 511120, 515112, 515120; Nombre: Mad Magazine; NAICS: 511120; Nombre: Turner Classic Movies; NAICS: 515120

Título: 1970 hit 'Love Story' is back in theaters. Go see it

Autor: Beckerman, Jim

Título de publicación: Daily Record; Morristown, N.J.

Primera página: D.2

Año de publicación: 2020

Fecha de publicación: Feb 8, 2020

Sección: Features

Editorial: Gannett Co Inc

Lugar de publicación: Morristown, N.J.

País de publicación: United States, Morristown, N.J.

Materia de publicación: General Interest Periodicals--United States

Idioma de la publicación: English

Tipo de documento: Feature

ID del documento de ProQuest: 2352277114

____________________________________________________________

Suitor to buy Mets: 'I gave it my best shot'

Autor: Toscano, Justin. 

Información de publicación: Asbury Park Press ; Asbury Park, N.J. [Asbury Park, N.J]. 08 Feb 2020: B.4.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/suitor-buy-mets-i-gave-my-best-shot/docview/2352277108/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Suitor+to+buy+Mets%3A+%27I+gave+it+my+best+shot%27&amp;author=Toscano%2C+Justin&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=B.4&amp;date=2020-02-08&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Asbury+Park+Press&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Manfred on Thursday said that any accusation that the Wilpons acted in bad faith was "completely and utterly unfair."
As the statement at the top of this story outlines, the Wilpons still intend to search for a new transaction. The timeline is unknown.
The Mets for years have been branded as the big-market team that rarely spends like it. Fans hoped Cohen — who would've been the richest owner in baseball — could immediately alter that perception.
It will have to be someone else, unless the two sides reconvene in the future.
This saga caps a wild offseason for the Mets, who ...
Fired a manager, hired a manager, parted with the first manager, hired a new manager. Oh, and that doesn't count the personnel moves and restructuring Yoenis Céspedes' contract.
Pitchers and catchers report to Port St. Lucie, Florida, for spring training next week. Finally, baseball will be the center of conversation — or at least you'd hope. But the Mets remained active, for better or worse, over the last four months.
On Tuesday, news broke that talks were not going well. But the fact that was leaked, some speculated, was a negotiation ploy.
It was not. There will be no deal between the Mets and Cohen.

State needs to enact a medical marijuana law

Información de publicación: The Post - Crescent ; Appleton, Wis. [Appleton, Wis]. 08 Feb 2020: A.8.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/state-needs-enact-medical-marijuana-law/docview/2352276898/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=State+needs+to+enact+a+medical+marijuana+law&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.8&amp;date=2020-02-08&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Post+-+Crescent&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Amidwestnews1_

Texto completo: The Wisconsin Legislature needs to come together and show compassion for suffering patients by enacting a medical cannabis law this year.
Patients and their doctors should be trusted to decide if medical cannabis is an appropriate treatment, just as they do for far more dangerous drugs, such as opiates.
Never has there been more of a true public understanding that marijuana reform is clearly needed in our state.
Robert Graf,
Kaukauna
Reader thanks League of Women Voters for hosting mayoral form Thanks League of Women Voters for hosting the mayoral forum. It's good to see several qualified and motivated candidates and several others who, in my view, are not.
Chad Doran and Jake Woodward know the importance of transparency (openess), particularly regarding the total cost of the bluff site for the U.S. Venture project and additional cost coming with a school referendum.
Dick Abb,
Appleton
Sen. Johnson is not representing his constituents Included in the U.S. Senate daily prayer Friday were the words you will "Reap what you sow." Our Wisconsin Senator, Ron Johnson (R-Oshkosh) let a large percentage of us down.
A Quinnipiac poll showed that 75% of people wanted a Yes vote for witnesses in the impeachment trial. Johnson voted No. He is not representing 75% of us, his constituents.
We have been cheated out of a fair trial and knowing the full truth in the Senate. Out of 15 impeachment trials there has never been a trial without witnesses. Johnson chose to follow his party and not represent his entire state.
He was also involved in the Ukraine controversy. Johnson was "troubled" by Trump's actions, but believed Trump's denial. Johnson was a fact witness and should not have served on the jury and had a vote at all. Stating "I represent the people that elected me," he refused to recuse himself. He clearly meant he represents only his party.
If we listen to the wise words of the Senate chaplain, Johnson will reap what he has sown and 75% of Wisconsin voters will vote him out of office.
Jill Trentlage,
Combined Locks
LBGT still face hurdles in workplace Workplace discrimination based on sexual orientation or gender identity had some discussion in the political realm last year. In the cases the Supreme Court discussed last October, the New York Times said one case was about two gay men who were fired because of their sexual orientation and the other about a transgender womanwho was fired for presenting as female at her workplace.
During the Supreme Court discussion of these two cases the justices discussed religious freedom in relation to LGBT customers and bathrooms. Although it makes sense for justices to compare the religious freedom cases because they were similar cases effecting the LGBT community, it did not make as much sense to spend so much of their discussion time talking about bathroom bills. Bathroom bills are an important issue for transgender folk but the issue did not have much to do with workplace discrimination.
The Supreme Court has yet to make an official decision about workplace protections. Not all LGBT workplace protections issues are being discussed at the federal level.
Last year, Wisconisin Gov. Tony Evers first executive order was banning workplace discrimination against LGBT people. According to Urban Milwaukee Wisconsin was one of 28 states without explicit workplace protections for transgender individuals until the executive order was made. The moral of these cases might be that it's easier to bring change at a state level compared to a federal level, but that change for LGBT individuals still takes time.
Sarah Williamsen,
Appleton
Country needs to come together and support president I think it is time that we as a country come together and support our president.
You may say I don't approve of his tweeting, how he combs his hair, how he may be critical of some people or whatever. Those are so insignificant it shouldn't matter when you look at the big picture.
Let's look at his job performance.
He has stimulated our economy with his tax cuts to corporations and individuals to a level we haven't seen in years.
He is taking on the Chinese leveling out the playing field with redoing our trade deals.
He has redone the Mexico-Canada trade agreement.
He is trying to rid Washington of all the corruption that has gone on for years.
He has brought God back into our government.
He is attempting to deal with the serious immigration problems that are costing our country billions of dollars.
He has rebuilt our military that has been neglected for years.
He has appointed great people to our Supreme Court.
He truly is making America Great Again.
Walt Edwards,
Greenville
Headline should not have singled out Gallagher I thought it inappropriate that the Post-Crescent singled-out Mike Gallagher in the front-page headline (Feb. 4) about accepting a political donation from a company producing PFAS contamination.
Buried on page 3 was the news that others, including Democrats, had received donations from the company also. Wouldn't it have been less-biased if the headline would have said politicians instead of just Gallagher?
Mike Pankratz,
Appleton
